{{Infobox company | name = GameFace Labs, LLC | logo = Gfl logo symbol-RGB(svg).svg | type = [[LLC]] | founders = {{plainlist| * Edward Mason, * Joseph Carter, * Vinny Rawlley, * Giacomo Eskenazi, * Mosbah Kahaleh, * Tareq Hawasli }} | foundation = {{Start date and age|2013|9}} in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | homepage = {{URL|http://gamefacelabs.com}} | location_city = [[San Francisco, California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | industry = [[Virtual reality]] }}
'''GameFace Labs''' is an American technology company that develops hardware and software solutions<ref>Maria Korolov (27-06-14). [http://www.hypergridbusiness.com/2014/06/gameface-building-vr-os-will-support-opensim/ “GameFace building virtual reality OS, will support OpenSim”]. ''Hypergrid Business''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref> for the consumer [[virtual reality]] market, and was founded in 2013 by Edward Mason. The company's headquarters are in [[San Francisco]], with international offices in [[London]], United Kingdom.
The company’s first product is a standalone headset that features an onboard [[Nvidia]] [[Tegra]] [[System on a chip|SoC]] (system on a chip) and does not require a tethered connection to a computer or console in order to operate.<ref>Brian Burke (16-03-2016).[https://blogs.nvidia.com/blog/2016/03/16/nvida-vr-gaming/ ”10 Ways NVIDIA Makes VR a Reality”]. ''Nvidia''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref> GameFace Labs is a founding member of the [[OSVR|Open Source Virtual Reality project]] (OSVR)<ref>Kevin Scarpati (06-01-2015). [http://www.razerzone.com/press/detail/press-releases/industry-leaders-announce-open-platform-for-virtual-reality-gaming “Industry Leaders Announce Open Platform for Virtual Reality Gaming”]. ''Razer''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref> and the Immersive Technology Alliance.<ref>Stephen Nunneley (13-03-2014). [https://www.vg247.com/2014/03/13/immersive-technology-alliance-formed-by-oculus-vr-ea-avegant-castar-others/ “Immersive Technology Alliance formed by Oculus VR, EA, Avegant, CastAR others”]. ''VG24/7''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref> In December 2015, GameFace Labs joined Valve’s [[OpenVR]] ecosystem.<ref>Maria Korolov (04-12-2015).[http://www.hypergridbusiness.com/2015/12/gameface-joins-valves-vr-ecosystem/ ”Gameface joins Valve’s VR ecosystem”]. ''HyperGrid Business''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref>
==Development== During [[Multiplay#Insomnia Gaming Festival|Insomnia Gaming Festival 49]] (2013), the company revealed its first prototype; a standalone headset featuring a 720p [[LCD]] display panel and an Nvidia [[Tegra 3]] SoC. At [[Consumer Electronics Show|CES]] 2014, the company showcased an updated prototype with a 1080p [[OLED]] display and a [[Tegra 4]] SoC.<ref>Ben Gilbert (13-01-2014). [https://www.engadget.com/2014/01/13/gameface-labs-hands-on-ces-2014/ “GameFace Mark IV: The other VR headset at CES 2014 (hands-on)”]. ''Engadget''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref>
In June 2014, the company showcased the first iteration of its user interface, allowing users to launch applications inside a virtual environment, as well as invite friends from other platforms to enjoy and collaborate on content inside the same virtual space.<ref>Maria Korolov (27-06-2014). [http://www.hypergridbusiness.com/2014/06/gameface-building-vr-os-will-support-opensim/ “GameFace building virtual reality OS, will support OpenSim”]. ''Hypergrid Business''. Retrieved 20 April 2017</ref> In June 2014, the company also demoed its Mk V prototype at [[E3]] - running on a version of Nvidia’s [[Tegra K1]] Soc.<ref>Ben Lang (10-06-2014). [http://www.roadtovr.com/e3-2014-gameface-labs-mark-5-prototype/ “First Look ‒ GameFace Labs Mark 5 Prototype, VR Never Looked So Good”]. ''Road To VR''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref> The Mk V headset was the first publicly demoed headset to include a 1440p display, which was supplied by [[Samsung]].<ref>Brandin Tyrrel (01-07-15). http://uk.ign.com/articles/2015/07/01/hands-on-with-gameface-labs-vr-headset “Hands-on with GameFace Labs’ VR Headset”]. ''IGN''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref>.<ref>Ben Lang (08-04-2014). [http://www.roadtovr.com/gameface-labs-first-vr-headset-block-2k-display-mobile/ “GameFace Labs Has the First VR Headset on the Block with a 2.5K Display—And It’s Mobile”]. ''Road to VR''. Retrieved 15 February 2017</ref> The K1 prototype utilized Nvidia’s mobile [[Kepler (microarchitecture)|Kepler]] architecture, which means it supported [[Android (operating system)|Android]] content that used [[DirectX 11]] and [[OpenGL#OpenGL 4.4|OpenGL 4.4]] and was also compatible with all [[Google Cardboard]] content.
At 2017’s [[E3]] expo, GameFace Labs demoed its seventh standalone prototype: a multi-platform headset supporting [[Android (operating system)|Android]] / [[Google Daydream|DayDream]] content, as well as full 6DoF positional tracking inside an Android environment. The prototype featured dual [[OLED]] display panels, low persistence display technology and support for [[6DoF]] input control via a wireless [[Infrared|IR]] beacon (in January 2018 the company revealed it had been developing an ARM-based implementation of Valve's generation 2 Lighthouse technology, using GameFace's custom firmware<ref>Scott Hayden (03-03-2018). [https://www.roadtovr.com/developers-now-receiving-steamvr-2-0-base-stations/ “Hardware Developers Are Now Receiving SteamVR 2.0 Base Stations”]. ''roadtovr.com''. Retrieved 05 March 2018.</ref> ). The company also showed off an Alpha build of its developer platform, allowing users to share and download content up to 1000x faster than traditional downloading methods.<ref>Nicole Lee (17-07-2017). [https://www.engadget.com/2017/07/17/gameface-labs-vr/ “In a Fragmented VR Market, one company wants to unite them all”]. Engadget.com''. Retrieved 31 July 2017.</ref>
In May 2018, GameFace Labs began shipping developer kits powered by Nvidia's TX2 SoC. This makes the GameFace Labs developer kit the first consumer electronics device to use the TX2, with Magic Leap announcing the second device later in July. <ref>Kevin Carbotte (11-07-2018). [https://www.tomshardware.com/news/magic-leap-tegra-specs-release,37443.html “Magic Leap One Powered by Nvidia Tegra TX2, Available Summer”]. ''Toms Hardware''. Retrieved 31 July 2018</ref> The GameFace Labs developer kit is the only system to pair the TX2 SoC with an Android Operating system. <ref>Kevin Carbotte (24-05-2018). [https://www.tomshardware.com/news/gameface-labs-standalone-steamvr-headset,37112.html “Nvidia's Jetson TX2 Powers GameFace Labs' Standalone VR Headset”]. ''Toms Hardware''. Retrieved 31 July 2018</ref>
==Awards== In 2014, GameFace Labs was awarded ‘Hack of Honor’ at the annual [[Penguicon]] open source convention<ref>Scott Kennedy (15-01-2014). [https://2014.penguicon.org/hack-of-honor-gameface-labs/ “HACK OF HONOR: GameFace Labs’ Android VR headset”]. ''Penguicon.org''. Retrieved 15 February 2017.</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Technology companies]] [[Category:Virtual reality companies]]

The [[Giro d'Italia]] ({{IPA-it|ˈdʒiːro diˈtaːlja}}; {{lang-en|Tour of Italy}}) is an annual [[stage race]] [[bicycle racing|bicycle race]] primarily held in [[Italy]], while also occasionally passing through nearby countries. The race was first organized in [[1909 Giro d'Italia|1909]] to increase sales of the newspaper ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]''; however it is currently run by [[RCS Sport]]. The race has been held annually since its first edition in 1909, except when it was stopped for the two [[world war]]s. As the Giro gained prominence and popularity the race was lengthened, and the peloton expanded from primarily Italian participation to riders from all over the world.
The first edition of the race was won by Italian [[Luigi Ganna]] who had the fewest total points at the end of the race; the same format was used for the next two years and also resulted in an Italian cyclist winning. The [[1912 Giro d'Italia|1912 Giro]] saw the [[General classification in the Giro d'Italia|general classification]] contested by teams, which [[Atala (cycling team)|Atala-Dunlop]] won by ten points. The [[1913 Giro d'Italia|following year]] they reverted to the original system, before switching to the aggregate time model in [[1914 Giro d'Italia|1914]]. [[Alfredo Binda]] won five editions of the race over a period of nine years, before [[Gino Bartali]] and [[Fausto Coppi]] consistently asserted their superiority in the Giro d'Italia. Italians dominated the race for forty years before the first non-Italian, [[Hugo Koblet]], in [[1950 Giro d'Italia|1950]].
After Koblet became the first foreigner to win the Giro, the Italians won the majority of the races held until [[1968 Giro d'Italia|1968]]. In 1968, the Belgian [[Eddy Merckx]] won his first Giro d'Italia, which were soon followed by four more victories. [[Bernard Hinault]] won the first of his three Giros d'Italia in [[1980 Giro d'Italia|1980]]. Ireland's [[Stephen Roche]] won the [[1987 Giro d'Italia|1987 race]] en route to winning the [[Triple Crown of Cycling]]. Spanish rider [[Miguel Indurain]] won two consecutive Giros d'Italia, in 1992 and 1993, with his victories being followed by wins by [[Evgeni Berzin]], [[Tony Rominger]], and [[Pavel Tonkov]]. The next ten editions of the race were won by Italian riders, including the likes of [[Marco Pantani]], [[Paolo Savoldelli]], and [[Gilberto Simoni]].
Spain's [[Alberto Contador]] won the [[2008 Giro d'Italia]] en route to completing the rare Giro-Vuelta double for the season. The [[2009 Giro d'Italia|2009 race]] celebrated the hundredth year since the first edition of the Giro d'Italia and was won by the Russian [[Denis Menchov]]. The [[2010 Giro d'Italia|following year]] saw [[Ivan Basso]] win his second overall race. Contador originally won the [[2011 Giro d'Italia]], but after a positive drug test result was found, his victory was stripped and given to [[Michele Scarponi]]. [[Vincenzo Nibali]], the winner of the 2013 race, led the event from the race's eighth stage and on.
==1908–1909: The idea and first race==
[[File:1234883933LuigiGanna-Milaan-1909.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Luigi Ganna]] the winner of the inaugural Giro d'Italia.|alt=A cyclist sitting down.]] The idea of the holding a bicycle race that navigated around Italy was first suggested when ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' editor [[Tullo Morgagni]] sent a telegram to both the paper's owner, Emilio Costamagna, and cycling editor, Armando Cougnet, stating the need for an Italian tour.{{sfn|Fotheringham|2003|p=103-104}}<ref name="BRI 1909">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1909.html |title=1909 Giro d'Italia |work=Bike Race Info |date= |author= Bill and Carol McGann |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> At the time ''La Gazzetta'''s rival, ''[[Corriere della Sera]]'' was planning on holding a bicycle race of its own, after the success they had gained from holding an automobile race.{{sfn|Fotheringham|2003|p=103-104}}<ref name="BRI 1909"/><ref name="gazzetta2005">{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Speciali/Giroditalia/2005/eng/storiadelgiro.html|title=History|work=La Gazzetta dello Sport|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> Morgagni then decided to try and hold their race before ''Corriere della Sera'' could hold theirs, but ''La Gazzetta'' lacked the money.<ref name="BRI 1909"/> However, after the success ''La Gazzetta'' had with creating the [[Giro di Lombardia]] and [[Milan–San Remo]], the owner Costamagna decided to go through with the idea.<ref name="BRI 1909"/><ref name="Pez Giro"/> Their bike race was announced on August 7, 1908 in the first page of that day's edition of ''La Gazzetta dello Sport''.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/> The race was to be held in May of 1909.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/> The idea of the race was inspired by the [[Tour de France]] and the success that ''[[L'Auto]]'' had gained from it.<ref name="Pez Giro">{{cite news|author=Leslie Reissner |url=http://www.pezcyclingnews.com/page/features/?id=84149#.UcXheZzNnsI|title=The Giro d’Italia: Don’t Go Home Yet! |date=23 June 2011|work=PezCycling News|accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="larousse1">{{cite web|url=http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/divers/Tour_dItalie/147186 |language=French |title=Tour d'Italie ou Giro d'Italia|work=Larousse|publisher=Real Media Group |date=30 March 2012 |accessdate=10 August 2012|trans-title=Tour of Italy or Giro d'Italia}}</ref>
Since the organizers lacked the funds, 25,000 [[lira]],{{sfn|Fotheringham|2003|p=103-104}} needed to hold the race, they consulted Primo Bongrani, an accountant at the bank Cassa di Risparmio and friend of the three organizers. Bongrani proceeded to go around Italy asking for donations to help hold the race.<ref name="BRI 1909"/> Bongrani's efforts were largely successful, he had procured enough money to cover the operating costs.<ref name="BRI 1909"/> The money that was to be given out as prizes came from a casino in [[Sanremo|San Remo]] after Francesco Sghirla, a former ''Gazzetta'' employee, encouraged it to contribute to the race.{{sfn|Fotheringham|2003|p=103-104}}<ref name="BRI 1909"/> Even ''Corriere'', ''La Gazzetta'''s rival, gave 3,000 lire to the race's fund.{{sfn|Fotheringham|2003|p=103-104}}
On 13 May 1909 at 02:53 am 127 riders started the first Giro d'Italia at Loreto Place in [[Milan]].<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="larousse1"/> The race was split into eight stages covering {{convert|2448|km|0|abbr=on}}.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/> A total of 49 riders finished, with Italian [[Luigi Ganna]] winning.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="1909 elm final">{{cite news |url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1909/06/10/pagina-3/607616/pdf.html |title=La Vuelta De Italia |language=Spanish |date=10 June 1909 |page=3 |newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo |accessdate=27 May 2012| format=PDF |trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref> Ganna won three individual stages and the General Classification.<ref name="1909 elm final"/> Ganna received 5325 lira as a winner’s prize, with the last rider in the general classification receiving 300 lira.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/> The Giro's director received only 150 lira a month, 150 lira fewer than the last-placed rider.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/>
==1910–1953: Italian domination==
During these years, and up until 1950, the winners of the Giro d'Italia were exclusively of Italian descent.<ref name="BRI 1950 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1950.html |title=1950 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The inaugural race was such a success that the organizers added two more stages and over {{convert|500|km|0|abbr=on}} to the race.<ref name="bikeraceinfo1">{{cite web|url=http://www.bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1910.html |title=1910 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> In addition, the organizers restructured the point distribution to determine the overall leader; the stage winner would get one point for finishing first, second place got two points, and so on until the 51st and up finishers, who would just receive 51 points.<ref name="bikeraceinfo1"/> The first non-Italian stage winner, [[Jean-Baptiste Dortignacq]], came in the [[1910 Giro d'Italia|1910 edition of the race]]; he won the second stage of the race.<ref name="bikeraceinfo1"/> [[Carlo Galetti]] led from stage two until the finish.<ref name="bikeraceinfo1"/><ref name="1910 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1910/06/16/pagina-3/618975/pdf.html|title=La Vuelta De Italia|language=Spanish|date=16 June 1910|page=3|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref> The [[1911 Giro d'Italia]] was the first Giro to not have the start or finish of the race in Milan.<ref name="bikeraceinfo2">{{cite web|url=http://www.bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1911.html |title=1911 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The start and finish for the race was moved to the Italian capital [[Rome]] to celebrate Italy's 50th anniversary of unification.<ref name="bikeraceinfo2"/> This race also saw the first foreign rider to lead the race, the Frenchmen [[Lucien Petit-Breton]], as well as the first repeat winner of the race in Carlo Galetti.<ref name="bikeraceinfo2"/><ref name="1911 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1911/06/15/pagina-3/1374492/pdf.html|title=La Vuelta De Italia|language=Spanish|date=15 June 1911|page=3|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref>
The [[1912 Giro d'Italia]] saw some big changes to how the general classification was to be run; the race was to be centered around the team instead of the individual, meaning that the leader of the race would be a single team.<ref name="bikeraceinfo3">{{cite web|url=http://www.bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1912.html |title=1912 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Teams were allowed only four riders for each squad and were awarded points towards the general classification based on stage placings.<ref name="bikeraceinfo3"/><ref name="cyclingrevealed1">{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclingrevealed.com/timeline/Race%20Snippets/GdI/GdI_1912.htm|author=Barry Boyce|title=Cycling Revealed Timeline|work=The Giro in 1912... A Team Competition |publisher=CyclingRevealed |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The changes to the general classification were met with strong opposition from the start.<ref name="bikeraceinfo3"/> Fourteen teams lined up at the start in Milan.<ref name="bikeraceinfo3"/><ref name="cyclingrevealed1"/> [[Atala (cycling team)|Atala-Dunlop]], which consisted of [[Luigi Ganna]], [[Carlo Galetti]], [[Eberardo Pavesi]], and [[Giovanni Micheletto]], led the race in all but one stage.<ref name="bikeraceinfo3"/><ref name="cyclingrevealed1"/><ref name="1912 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1912/06/13/pagina-4/1385665/pdf.html|title=La Vuelta De Italia|language=Spanish|date=13 June 1912|page=4|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref> Ganna was the only member of Atala-Dunlop that didn't finish the race, as he dropped out during the fifth stage. Galetti became the first three-time winner of the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="bikeraceinfo3"/>
[[File:Girardengo.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Costante Girardengo]] was the first rider to lead a Giro d'Italia from start to finish.|alt=A cyclist having his picture taken.]] The [[1913 Giro d'Italia|following year's race]] was the last Giro to be run with a points system.<ref name="BRI 1913 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1913.html |title=1913 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The race saw the first appearance of [[Costante Girardengo]], who won the sixth stage, and would come to dominate the Giro in the future.<ref name="BRI 1913 Giro"/> [[Carlo Oriani]] — who had just gotten out of serving the Italian military in the [[Italo-Turkish War]] — won the event by six points over the second-place finisher, [[Eberardo Pavesi]].<ref name="BRI 1913 Giro"/><ref name="1913p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1913/05/29/pagina-3/606537/pdf.html|title=La Vuelta De Italia|language=Spanish|date=29 May 1913|page=3|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref><ref name="1913p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1913/05/29/pagina-4/1383034/pdf.html|title=La Vuelta De Italia|language=Spanish|date=29 May 1913|page=4|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref> The [[1914 Giro d'Italia]] saw the calculation of the general classification shift from a points system to a time based system.<ref name="BRI 1914 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1914.html |title=1914 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> In the new system, every rider's finishing time for each stage is totaled together and the rider with the lowest total time is the overall leader.<ref name="BRI 1914 Giro"/> Out of the eighty-one riders entered the race only eight of them finished.<ref name="BRI 1914 Giro"/><ref name="1914 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1914/06/11/pagina-3/1394122/pdf.html|title=La Vuelta De Italia|language=Spanish|date=29 May 1913|page=4|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia}}</ref> The grueling race was won by [[Alfonso Calzolari]], who won by almost two hours over the second-place finisher.<ref name="BRI 1914 Giro"/><ref name="1914 elm final"/> A Giro was planned for 1915, but the plans were scrapped when Italy entered [[World War I]].<ref name="BRI 1914 Giro"/>
After the Great War ended, the race resumed in [[1919 Giro d'Italia|1919]].<ref name="Livestrong Giro Info">{{cite news|url=http://www.livestrong.com/article/344716-the-history-of-the-giro-ditalia/|title=The History of the Giro d'Italia.|author=Gregg Seltzer|publisher=Livestrong|date=26 May 2011|accessdate=30 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="BRI 1919 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1919.html |title=1919 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> This edition of the race navigated through the ruined parts of Northern Italy, which made it hard for the organizers and riders.<ref name="BRI 1919 Giro"/> [[Costante Girardengo]] — the eventual winner — became the first rider to lead the Giro from start to finish.<ref name="BRI 1919 Giro"/> En route to winning overall, Girardengo won seven of the ten stages that composed the event.<ref name="larousse1"/> In addition, the Belgian [[Marcel Buysse]] became the first foreigner to finish on the podium;<ref name="BRI 1919 Giro"/> Buysse finished third overall, over an hour slower than Girardengo.<ref name="BRI 1919 Giro"/> The following year's Giro began with close to fifty riders and finished with ten.<ref name="BRI 1920 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1920.html |title=1920 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The first stage of the [[1920 Giro d'Italia]] briefly went into [[Switzerland]], which was the first time that the Giro had ever left its home country of Italy.<ref name="BRI 1920 Giro"/> Girardengo came into the race the favorite, but injuries sustained from crashing in the second stage forced him to withdraw.<ref name="BRI 1920 Giro"/> During the second stage, [[Gaetano Belloni]] capitalized on Girardengo's, race leader Giuseppe Olivieri's, Carlo Galetti's withdrawal to win the second stage and take the lead.<ref name="BRI 1920 Giro"/> Belloni, known by many as "the Eternal Second, went on to win the Giro and proved he could win a race.<ref name="BRI 1920 Giro"/>{{sfn|Foot|2011|p=48}}
[[Costante Girardengo]] won the first four stages of the [[1921 Giro d'Italia]] and was leader after the fourth day.<ref name="BRI 1921 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1921.html |title=1921 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> During the fifth stage, Girardengo was involved in a crash, and when Gaetano Belloni saw this, he attacked.<ref name="BRI 1921 Giro"/> Girardengo chased for {{convert|60|km|0|abbr=on}} before quitting.<ref name="BRI 1921 Giro"/> Belloni was then the new leader after stage 5's conclusion.<ref name="BRI 1921 Giro"/> After the fifth stage, [[Giovanni Brunero]] was the only rider close to Belloni.<ref name="BRI 1921 Giro"/> Brunero attacked during the race's seventh stage to win the day and take the overall lead by fifty-two seconds, which proved enough to last until the race's conclusion in Milan.<ref name="BRI 1921 Giro"/> The [[1922 Giro d'Italia]] saw some controversy amongst the general classification contenders.<ref name="BRI 1922 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1922.html |title=1922 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> In the race's first stage, Giovanni Brunero received an illegal wheel change – Brunero took a wheel from his teammate Alfredo Sivocci – which he was penalized 25 minutes for.<ref name="BRI 1922 Giro"/> Costante Girardengo and Gaetono Belloni, along with their respective teams Maino and Bianchi, wanted Brunero to be expelled from the Giro for the incident.<ref name="BRI 1922 Giro"/> Both the Bianchi and Maino squads eventually withdrew from the Giro due to their outrage with the organizer's decision to only give Brunero a 25-minute penalty.<ref name="BRI 1922 Giro"/> Brunero went on to win the Giro d'Italia, the second one of his career.<ref name="BRI 1922 Giro"/>
The [[1923 Giro d'Italia]] was dominated by [[Costante Girardengo]], who won eight out of the ten race's stages.<ref name="BRI 1923 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1923.html |title=1923 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Despite the large amount of stage victories, Girardengo's margin of victory was thirty-seven seconds over the second-place finisher [[Giovanni Brunero]].<ref name="BRI 1923 Giro"/> This was Girardengo's second career Giro victory.<ref name="BRI 1923 Giro"/> Girardengo, Brunero, and [[Gaetano Belloni]] didn't start the [[1924 Giro d'Italia|1924 edition]] due to an argument over their compensation.<ref name="BRI 1924 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1924.html |title=1924 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Their decision not to participate gave the other general classification hopefuls a bigger chance to win the Giro.<ref name="BRI 1924 Giro"/> After the event's eighth leg that saw awful road and weather conditions, [[Giuseppe Enrici]] emerged as the overall leader and eventual winner.<ref name="BRI 1924 Giro"/> In addition, this Giro saw the first and only woman ever to compete in the race's history in [[Alfonsina Strada]].<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1924 Giro"/> She was eliminated from the race after the seventh stage; however, the organizers allowed her to continue the race thought she wouldn't be included in the general classification.<ref name="BRI 1924 Giro"/> Strada made it all the way to the event's finish in Milan and finished around twenty hours slower than the winner Enrici.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1924 Giro"/>
===1925–1935: The Binda years===
The [[1925 Giro d'Italia]] saw the emergence of a new star, [[Alfredo Binda]].<ref name="BRI 1925 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1925.html |title=1925 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Despite winning six legs of the event, [[Costante Girardengo]] did not win the race.<ref name="BRI 1925 Giro"/> Binda gained the lead after the fifth stage, after he and a few other general classification contenders attacked while Girardengo was repairing a flat tire.<ref name="BRI 1925 Giro"/> Binda won the Giro in his first attempt.<ref name="BRI 1925 Giro"/> Reigning champion Binda started off the [[1926 Giro d'Italia|following year's race]] with a crash in the first stage, which caused him to lose lots of time.<ref name="BRI 1926 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1926.html |title=1926 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Due to the crash, Binda worked as a domestique for his teammate [[Giovanni Brunero]].<ref name="BRI 1926 Giro"/> With Binda's aid, Brunero won the whole event, while Binda won six stages.<ref name="BRI 1926 Giro"/>
Before the [[1927 Giro d'Italia]], the organizers made some changes: the stage winner now received a one-minute time bonus and stages were now occasionally run on consecutive days, where before they had at least one rest day before each stage.<ref name="BRI 1927 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1927.html |title=1927 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The event witnessed Alfredo Binda win twelve stages and lead the race from start to finish en route to his second overall victory.<ref name="BRI 1927 Giro"/> Binda's record of twelve stage wins in a single Giro still stands.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1927 Giro"/> Binda returned the [[1928 Giro d'Italia|next year]] to win six of the twelve stages, along with the race as a whole.<ref name="BRI 1928 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1928.html |title=1928 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> He first captured the lead after the fourth stage, where he significantly distanced himself from his competitors.<ref name="BRI 1928 Giro"/> Binda became the second person to win three Giro d'Italias in their career.<ref name="BRI 1928 Giro"/> In addition, the event saw a record number of participants at 298 riders, of which 126 finished the race.<ref name="BRI 1928 Giro"/>
In [[1929 Giro d'Italia|1929]] Alfredo Binda won a record eight consecutive stages on the way to his third consecutive, and fourth career, Giro d'Italia victory.<ref name="BRI 1929 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1929.html |title=1929 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="The Giro's 100th Anniversary">{{cite web|url=http://paris.thover.com/article/142/fr/le-parcours-du-giro-d-italia-2009---le-tour-d-italie-fete-son-100eme-anniversaire-comme-il-se-doit.html|title=le Tour d'Italie fête son 100ème anniversaire comme il se doit|work=Velowire|language=French|date=15 December 2008|accessdate=15 September 2010}}</ref> This Giro began in [[Rome]], which was the second time that the Giro had not started in Milan in the history of its running.<ref name="BRI 1929 Giro"/> When Binda came to the finish in Milan, he was booed by some of the spectators.<ref name="BRI 1929 Giro"/> The next year, Binda was paid 22,500 lire — the same amount of money the winner of the Giro would get — not to participate in the Giro.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1930 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1930.html |title=1930 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Binda's absence left the field open for everyone else.<ref name="BRI 1930 Giro"/> The eventual winner, [[Luigi Marchisio]], gained the lead after winning the third stage of the race.<ref name="BRI 1930 Giro"/> Marchisio held a slim fifty-two second lead for the last six stages of the race to the finish in Milan.<ref name="BRI 1930 Giro"/> Marchisio became the youngest rider to win the Giro at 21 years, 1 month, and 13 days; his record stood for ten years before being broken by [[Fausto Coppi]].<ref name="BRI 1930 Giro"/>
[[File:Alfredo Binda 1924.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Alfredo Binda]] (right) was the first rider to win the Giro d'Italia five times.|alt=A man standing and drinking from a water bottle.]] The famed race [[general classification in the Giro d'Italia|general classification]] leader's pink jersey ({{lang-it|maglia rosa}}) was introduced in [[1931 Giro d'Italia|1931]].<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1931 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1931.html |title=1931 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The color pink was chosen for the leader's jersey because [[La Gazzetta dello Sport]] printed its news on pink paper.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/> The maglia rosa was first worn by [[Learco Guerra]], who won the first stage of the race.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1931 Giro"/> Alfredo Binda returned to the Giro after his absence the year before, but withdrew while leading during the sixth stage.<ref name="BRI 1931 Giro"/> The eventual winner, [[Francesco Camusso]], attacked during the eleventh stage to claim the lead of the race.<ref name="BRI 1931 Giro"/> Binda came into the [[1932 Giro d'Italia]] in poor form, so he decided to work for his teammate [[Antonio Pesenti]].<ref name="BRI 1932 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1932.html |title=1932 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> During the seventh stage of the race, Pesenti gained the lead of the race by winning the stage by means of a solo attack and went on to win the event as a whole.<ref name="BRI 1932 Giro"/>
The [[Mountains classification in the Giro d'Italia|mountains classification]] and the [[individual time trial]] were both introduced in the [[1933 Giro d'Italia]].<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1933.html |title=1933 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The mountains classification awarded points to the riders who crossed certain mountains on the race route first and the rider with the most points was the leader.<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/> In addition, the organizers also expanded the total number of stages to seventeen, it had been around twelve the few preceding years.<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/> [[Alfredo Binda]] gained the lead after the second stage, but lost it to [[Jef Demuysere]] after the fifth stage.<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/> After the eighth stage, Binda regained the lead and had a six-minute advantage over Demuysere.<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/> Binda won the next three stages and went on to win the race as a whole.<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/> Along with winning the general classification, Binda won the inaugural mountains classification.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/> By winning this edition of the Giro, Binda became the first five-time winner of the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1933 Giro"/>
[[Learco Guerra]] won ten of the seventeen stages that comprised the [[1934 Giro d'Italia]].<ref name="BRI 1934 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1934.html |title=1934 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> After Alfredo Binda abandoned the race because of injuries sustained from being hit by a police motorcycle, Guerra's biggest competitor was [[Francesco Camusso]].<ref name="BRI 1934 Giro"/><ref name="Ouest-France">{{cite news|url=http://ouestfrance.cd-script.fr/opdf/1934/05/26/85/1934-05-26_85_07.pdf|title=Guerra remporte la 5th étape du Tour d'Italie|language=French|date=26 May 1933|page=46|publisher=Ouest-France|accessdate=26 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Guerra wins the 5th stage of the Giro d'Italia}}</ref> Camusso gained the lead after his stage thirteen performance.<ref name="BRI 1934 Giro"/> The race's fourteenth stage was a time trial and Camusso lost over four minutes to Guerra because of his poor performance on the day.<ref name="BRI 1934 Giro"/> The two riders battled all the way to Milan, but Guerra won by a margin of fifty-one seconds.<ref name="BRI 1934 Giro"/> The [[1935 Giro d'Italia|1935 edition of the Giro]] saw some changes to how it was run: the organizers removed the time bonuses for winning stages and began to make use of half stages — which is when two legs are held in the same day.<ref name="BRI 1935 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1935.html |title=1935 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> This race was the last time Alfredo Binda competed and the first time future great [[Gino Bartali]] participated.<ref name="BRI 1935 Giro"/> The eventual winner, [[Vasco Bergamaschi]], originally came to the Giro to work for his teammate, the great [[Costante Girardengo]].<ref name="BRI 1935 Giro"/> However, he gained the lead for a day after the first stage and regained it again after the sixth day of racing.<ref name="BRI 1935 Giro"/>
===1936–1953: Bartali and Coppi battle for supremacy===
[[File:Fausto Coppi, Tour de France 1952 01 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Fausto Coppi]] won the Giro d'Italia a record five times.|alt=A black and white photo of a man in front of a crowd of people.]] Due to Italy's political stance at the time, the [[1936 Giro d'Italia]] saw no foreign participation.<ref name="BRI 1936 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1936.html |title=1936 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The organizers of the race included the first uphill [[individual time trial]] in the Giro's history, which traveled {{convert|20|km|0|abbr=on}} up to the summit of [[Monte Terminillo]].<ref name="BRI 1936 Giro"/> [[Gino Bartali]] took the lead of the race by attacking on the final climb of the hilly ninth stage and held that lead to the event's conclusion.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1936 Giro"/> In addition to the general classification, Bartali won his second consecutive mountains classification title.<ref name="BRI 1936 Giro"/> For the [[1937 Giro d'Italia]] the organizers decided to include the [[Dolomites]] and a [[team time trial]] for the first time.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="Le Giro a 100 ans">{{cite web|url=http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/article/Le_Giro_a_100_ans/11018987|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130213131208/http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/article/Le_Giro_a_100_ans/11018987|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 February 2013|title=Le Giro a 100 ans|language=French|work=larousse.fr|accessdate=16 September 2010|trans-title=The Giro d'Italia is 100 Years Old}}</ref><ref name="BRI 1937 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1937.html |title=1937 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The team time trial lasted {{convert|62|km|0|abbr=on}} and was won by Legnano, the team of the eventual winner Gino Bartali.<ref name="BRI 1937 Giro"/> Bartali displayed his dominance in the mountains and gained the lead after the uphill stage 8a time trial.<ref name="BRI 1937 Giro"/> Bartali carried the pink jersey all the way to Milan and won his second consecutive Giro d'Italia.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1937 Giro"/>
Gino Bartali, the winner of the past two editions, was ordered by the Italian government to race the [[Tour de France]] instead of the Giro in 1938.<ref name="BRI 1938 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1938.html |title=1938 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> [[Giovanni Valetti]] took the lead of the [[1938 Giro d'Italia]] after the mountainous ninth stage.<ref name="BRI 1938 Giro"/> Valetti had a lead of a minute and a half after that stage and built upon that as the Giro went on, finishing almost nine minutes ahead of the second place rider [[Ezio Cecchi]].<ref name="BRI 1938 Giro"/> The [[1939 Giro d'Italia]] was a battle between Gino Bartali and Giovanni Valetti.<ref name="BRI 1939 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1939.html |title=1939 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Valetti took the lead after the stage 9b individual time trial.<ref name="BRI 1939 Giro"/> Bartali became the leader after he had attacked on the [[Passo Rolle]] during the fifteenth stage.<ref name="BRI 1939 Giro"/> Bartali lost the lead to Valetti because he crashed and had several flat tires throughout the sixteenth stage.<ref name="BRI 1939 Giro"/> Valetti won his second consecutive Giro d'Italia, while Bartali left the Giro with his fourth mountains classification title.<ref name="Le Giro a 100 ans"/><ref name="BRI 1939 Giro"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/article/Le_Giro_a_100_ans/11018987|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130213131208/http://www.larousse.fr/encyclopedie/article/Le_Giro_a_100_ans/11018987|dead-url=yes|archive-date=13 February 2013|title=Le Giro a 100 ans|publisher=larousse.fr|accessdate=16 September 2010}}</ref>
Bartali came to the [[1940 Giro d'Italia]] with a strong Legnano team and high ambitions to win the overall crown; however his hopes were derailed when he crashed in the race's second stage and lost time.<ref name="BRI 1940 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1940.html |title=1940 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> [[Fausto Coppi]] was promoted to the new team leader after Bartali's misfortunes.<ref name="BRI 1940 Giro"/> Coppi donned the [[general classification in the Giro d'Italia|general classification]] leader's pink jersey after attacking on the [[Abetone]] in the race's eleventh stage and managed to keep the lead all the way to the event's finish in Milan.<ref name="BRI 1940 Giro"/><ref name="Il y a 50 ans, Fausto Coppi nous quittait" /> Coppi became the youngest rider to ever win the Giro at 20 years, 8 months and 25 days old, breaking the record that was held by [[Luigi Marchisio]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/28052010/58/giro-d-italia-top-five-giro-d-italia-finishes.html |title=Top five:Giro d'Italia finishes |work=Eurosport|publisher=Yahoo! and Eurosport|date=24 May 2010|accessdate=4 September 2010|author=Eurosport}}</ref> [[World War II]] brought the Giro's annual running to a halt after the 1940 edition.<ref name="Livestrong Giro Info"/><ref name="BRI 1940 Giro"/>
[[File:Fiorenzo Magni GP Maino 1939.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Fiorenzo Magni]] won the Giro d'Italia in [[1948 Giro d'Italia|1948]] by a margin of eleven seconds.|alt=A man wearing a white jersey with goggles around is neck holding a bunch of flowers.]] [[Benito Mussolini]], Italy's dictator at the time, tried to keep the bicycle races going while Italy was involved in the Second World War.<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1941.html |title=1941 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The Giro consumed so much gasoline, food, and other supplies that it would hinder Italy's efforts towards the war, so the normal Giro was not run.<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945"/> The government created a new "point series" Giro that was composed of the major one day races that were run in Italy, where the riders would earn points based on their placing in each race.<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945"/> Some of the notable races that comprised this "Giro" were the [[Milan–San Remo]] and the [[Giro di Lombardia]].<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945"/> The new "point series" Giro was first won by Gino Bartali in 1942.<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945"/> The 1943 edition of the government's Giro was interrupted after Allie forces landed in [[Sicily]] and was subsequently Mussolini deposed.<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945"/> With Mussolini's reign over, bicycle racing came to a complete stop in Italy.<ref name="BRI Giro between 1941-1945"/>
The Giro resumed its annual running in [[1946 Giro d'Italia|1946]].<ref name="BRI 1946 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1946.html |title=1946 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The organizers added the ''[[maglia nera]]'' ({{lang-en|black jersey}}) for the last rider in the overall classification.<ref name="gazzetta1">{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.it/Ciclismo/Primo_Piano/2008/01_Gennaio/11/numero_nero_1101.shtml |title=Giro, la Maglia nera diventa Numero nero |language=Italian |work=La Gazzetta dello Sport|publisher=RCS MediaGroup|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]|date=11 January 2008|accessdate=4 August 2012|trans-title=The Giro, the black jersey becomes the black number}}</ref> Bartali and Coppi returned to the Giro now on separate teams.<ref name="BRI 1946 Giro"/> Coppi was put into difficulty in stage nine, where he lost a good deal of time.<ref name="BRI 1946 Giro"/> The twelfth stage was set to pass through [[San Canzian d'Isonzo|Pieris]] on the way to [[Trieste]]; however, in Pieris there were some Yugoslavs who threw stones at some armed Italian guards.<ref name="BRI 1946 Giro"/> Gunfire erupted, the stage was cancelled, and close to twenty riders were escorted to Trieste.<ref name="BRI 1946 Giro"/> In addition, there were riots that took place in Trieste because both [[Yugoslavia]] and [[Italy]] claimed the city as part of their territory.<ref name="BRI 1946 Giro"/> Bartali gained the lead after the thirteenth stage of the race and went on to win the event without winning a stage.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1946 Giro"/>
The [[1947 Giro d'Italia]] was the first Giro to have all competing riders be a part of a trade team, rather than some riders competing as independents.<ref name="BRI 1947 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1947.html |title=1947 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Fausto Coppi, Gino bartali, and [[Aldo Ronconi]] broke away during the fourth leg while climbing the [[Abetone]] and rode into [[Prato]] where Coppi won the stage and Bartali took the overall lead.<ref name="BRI 1947 Giro"/> Bartali held that lead until the sixteenth stage when his chain dropped on the climb of the [[Falzarego Pass|Falzarego]] when Coppi saw this he attacked.<ref name="BRI 1947 Giro"/> On the descent of the Falzarego, the same misfortune struck Coppi, which allowed Bartali to rejoin him.<ref name="BRI 1947 Giro"/> Later, Coppi attacked on the [[Passo Pordoi]] and Bartali could not keep up.<ref name="BRI 1947 Giro"/> Coppi took the stage and the overall lead, which he held all the way to race's finish.<ref name="BRI 1947 Giro"/> [[Fiorenzo Magni]] won the [[1948 Giro d'Italia]] by a margin of eleven seconds — the smallest margin of victory in the history of the race — over [[Ezio Cecchi]].<ref name="BRI 1948 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1948.html |title=1948 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Magni gained significant time after being a part of a successful breakaway in the race's ninth day of racing.<ref name="BRI 1948 Giro"/> Magni's lead over race favorites Coppi and Bartali was near thirteen minutes.<ref name="BRI 1948 Giro"/> Cecchi briefly gained the lead of the race for two stages; however, Magni took the lead after the seventeenth stage which saw riders cross the Pordoi Pass.<ref name="BRI 1948 Giro"/> Coppi and his team suspected that Magni received help from the spectators, which the organizers gave Magni a two-minute penalty for.<ref name="BRI 1948 Giro"/> The penalty to Magni wasn't enough to prevent him from winning the race, but he did so by the slimmest of margins.<ref name="BRI 1948 Giro"/>
[[File:Hugo Koblet (1951)-a.jpg|thumb|upright|The Swiss rider [[Hugo Koblet]] was the first foreign rider to win the Giro d'Italia.|alt=A cyclist wearing a jersey with a cross on it.]] After the ninth stage of the [[1949 Giro d'Italia|1949 edition]], Fausto Coppi was close to ten minutes behind the race leader [[Adolfo Leoni]] in the general classification.<ref name="BRI 1949 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1949.html |title=1949 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Coppi gained over nine minutes on Leoni during the tenth stage, but Leoni remained in the lead.<ref name="BRI 1949 Giro"/> The race's seventeenth leg went over five major climbs before finishing in [[Pinerolo]].<ref name="Il y a 50 ans, Fausto Coppi nous quittait">{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclismactu.net/news-divers_il_y_a_50_ans__fausto_coppi_nous_quittait-4255.html|title=Il y a 50 ans, Fausto Coppi nous quittait |language=French|work=Cyclism'Actu|publisher=Swar-Agency Swar Agency SPRLS|date=2 January 2010|accessdate=16 September 2010|trans-title=He was 50 years old, Fausto Coppi has left us|author=Sébastien Berbey}}</ref><ref name="BRI 1949 Giro"/> Coppi attacked off the start and was the first over all the climbs and the finish line in Pinerolo; his efforts gained him the race lead and a sizable lead over his rival Gino Bartali.<ref name="BRI 1949 Giro"/> Coppi went on to win the Giro, his third such victory.<ref name="BRI 1949 Giro"/><ref name="1949 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1949/06/15/pagina-2/664719/pdf.html#|title=Coppi gana la Vuelta a Italia|language=Spanish|date=15 June 1949|page=2|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Coppi Wins the Tour of Italy|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Coppi came into the [[1950 Giro d'Italia]] as the favorite to win the general classification; however, bad luck struck as he broke his pelvis in the race's ninth day.<ref name="BRI 1950 Giro"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asport.fr/EquipeMag/Top5/top-5-des-etrangers-vainqueurs-du-giro-20090511_105634.html|title=TOP 5 DES ÉTRANGERS VAINQUEURS DU GIRO|work=L'Equipe Magazine|publisher=Amaury Sports Organization|accessdate=20 June 2013|language=French|trans-title=Top 5 Foreign Winners of the Giro|author=Vincent Hubé}}</ref> In the eighth leg, [[Hugo Koblet]] attacked on the Pian delle Fugazze to win the stage and gain the overall lead.<ref name="BRI 1950 Giro"/> Koblet kept the lead all the way to the Giro's finish in Milan and in doing so he became the first foreigner to win the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1950 Giro"/><ref name="1950 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1950/06/14/pagina-1/666377/pdf.html#|title=El suizo Koblet|language=Spanish|date=14 June 1950|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=The Swiss Koblet|location=[[Rome]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> In addition, Koblet won the mountains classification.<ref name="BRI 1950 Giro"/>
Almost three years after his first Giro d'Italia victory, [[Fiorenzo Magni]] won the Giro d'Italia again.<ref name="BRI 1951 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1951.html |title=1951 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Magni's major rival in the [[1951 Giro d'Italia|1951 edition]] was the Belgian [[Rik Van Steenbergen]] who performed very well in the [[Dolomites]].<ref name="BRI 1951 Giro"/> Magni took the lead after descending successfully down the final climb of the eighteenth stage and then protecting the lead all way to the race's finish.<ref name="BRI 1951 Giro"/><ref name="1951 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1951/06/11/pagina-2/1340633/pdf.html#|title=Magni gana la Vuelta a Italia|language=Spanish|date=11 June 1951|page=2|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Magni wins the Tour of Italy|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> The [[1952 Giro d'Italia]] featured one of the first deaths by a rider in the Giro in Orfeo Ponsin who died from complications after crashing into a tree on the descent of the Merluzza.<ref name="BRI 1952 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1952.html |title=1952 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> [[Fausto Coppi]] took the race lead upon the tenth stage's finish, but the following day he attacked on the [[Passo Pordoi]] and rode the rest of the stage by himself to increase his lead.<ref name="BRI 1952 Giro"/> Coppi won two stages after gaining the overall lead, which further cemented his lead in the race.<ref name="BRI 1952 Giro"/><ref name="1952 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1952/06/09/pagina-6/635384/pdf.html#|title=Coppi Vencedor De La Vuelta A Italia|language=Spanish|date=9 June 1952|page=6|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Coppi the Winner of the Tour of Italy|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
The Swiss rider [[Hugo Koblet]] gained the lead of the [[1953 Giro d'Italia]] after the race's stage eight individual time trial.<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1953.html |title=1953 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Koblet defended the successfully lead from Fausto Coppi up until the twentieth stage that contained the [[Passo dello Stelvio]].<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro"/> The night before the twentieth stage, Koblet overused [[amphetamines]], which made him uneasy throughout the stage.<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro"/> Kolbet marked an attack on the ascent of the Stelvio while showing signs of weakness.<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro"/> Coppi heard of Koblet's drug use and attacked.<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro"/> Koblet was unable to match Coppi's move and Coppi went on to win the stage and take the race lead.<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro"/><ref name="1953p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1953/06/03/pagina-1/1353205/pdf.html#|title=Coppi, en la penúltima etapa se impuso, y ha ganado de nuevo la Vuelta Ciclista a Italia :: Koblet, segundo|language=Spanish|date=3 June 1953|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Coppi, Won the Penultimate Stage, and Won the Tour of Italy Again :: Koblet, Second|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref><ref name="1953p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1953/06/03/pagina-3/638238/pdf.html#|title=Coppi en la penúltima|language=Spanish|date=3 June 1953|page=3|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Coppi in the penultimate|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> The time gap proved to be enough and Coppi won a record tying five Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1953 Giro"/><ref name="1953p1 elm final"/><ref name="1953p2 elm final"/>
==1954–1967: Italian supremacy challenged==
[[File:Charly Gaul, Neluxploeg 1959.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Charly Gaul]] won the Giro d'Italia twice in his career.|alt=A man wearing a white cap.]] The tensions at the start of the race in [[1954 Giro d'Italia|1954]] were high because the organizers paid [[Fausto Coppi]] a large sum to participate in the race<ref name="BRI 1954 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1954.html |title=1954 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The transaction angered the peloton and led to the race being not highly contested; this was extremely evident on the twenty-first stage when the riders took over nine hours to complete the {{convert|222|km|0|abbr=on}} stage.<ref name="BRI 1954 Giro"/> Eventual winner [[Carlo Clerici]] attacked during the sixth leg and gained enough of a time advantage over the rest of the peloton and win the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1954 Giro"/><ref name="1954p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1954/06/14/pagina-1/629698/pdf.html#|title=Dos suizos y un belga|language=Spanish|date=14 June 1954|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Two Swiss and a Belgian|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref><ref name="1954p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1954/06/14/pagina-6/629703/pdf.html#|title=Dos suizos y un belga|language=Spanish|date=14 June 1954|page=6|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Two Swiss and a Belgian|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> [[Fiorenzo Magni]] led the majority of the first half of the [[1955 Giro d'Italia]] before losing the lead to another rider.<ref name="BRI 1955 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1955.html |title=1955 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> During the twentieth leg, Magni attacked with Fausto Coppi when his fellow competitors had stopped to change their tires.<ref name="BRI 1955 Giro"/> Magni's efforts gave him the race lead and ultiamtely his third Giro d'Italia victory.<ref name="BRI 1955 Giro"/><ref name="1955p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1955/06/06/pagina-1/627528/pdf.html#|title=Termino La Vuelta A Italia Con La Victoria De Magni|language=Spanish|date=6 June 1955|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Final The Tour of Italy with the Victory by Magni|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref><ref name="1955p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1955/06/06/pagina-6/627531/pdf.html#|title=Terminó la Vuelta a Italia|language=Spanish|date=6 June 1955|page=6|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Final the Tour of Italy|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
The [[1956 Giro d'Italia|1956 edition of the Giro]] was without much drama until the twenty-first stage that stretched from [[Merano]] to the summit finish on Monte Bondone, a mountain in the [[Dolomites]].<ref name="BRI 1956 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1956.html |title=1956 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The stage was bitterly cold with temperatures near {{convert|-10|°C|0|abbr=on}} that forced over sixty riders to abandon the race including the race leader [[Pasquale Fornara]].<ref name="BRI 1956 Giro"/>{{sfn|Foot|2011|p=198}} [[Charly Gaul]] attacked during the stage and won the stage, while also gaining enough time to take the lead.<ref name="BRI 1956 Giro"/>{{sfn|Foot|2011|p=198}}<ref name="1956p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1956/06/11/pagina-1/636586/pdf.html#|title=Gaul Vencedor Del "Giro"|language=Spanish|date=14 June 1956|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Gaul the Winner of the "Tour"|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref><ref name="1956p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1956/06/11/pagina-5/636590/pdf.html#|title=Gaul, Vencedor Del "Giro"|language=Spanish|date=14 June 1956|page=5|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Gaul, the Winner of the "Tour"|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> After the Gaul crossed the stage's finish, he was taken to the hospital because his jersey was stuck to his skin.<ref name="Monte Bondone 56, l’Everest de Charly Gaul">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportvox.fr/article.php3?id_article=27018|title=Monte Bondone 56, l’Everest de Charly Gaul|work=SportVox|publisher=Amaury Sports Organization|date=6 April 2010|accessdate=20 September 2010}}</ref> Gaul won the race and became the first Luxembourgian rider to win the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1956 Giro"/><ref name="1956p1 elm final"/><ref name="1956p2 elm final"/> Gaul returned to the race in [[1957 Giro d'Italia|1957]] and regained the {{clarify|date=February 2017}} after the sixteenth leg.<ref name="BRI 1957 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1957.html |title=1957 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> During the eighteenth stage, Gaul stopped to urinate which led his fierce rival [[Louison Bobet]] to initiate an attack with [[Gastone Nencini]] and [[Miguel Poblet]].<ref name="BRI 1957 Giro"/> Gaul lost to Nencini; however, Gaul took out his frustration by aiding Nencini with his bid to win just to spite Bobet.<ref name="BRI 1957 Giro"/> With Gaul's help, Nencini went on to win the event by nineteen seconds over Bobet.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1957 Giro"/><ref name="1957p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1957/06/10/pagina-1/640933/pdf.html#|title=Final Apoteótico Del "Giro" En Milan|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1957|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref><ref name="1957p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1957/06/10/pagina-7/640937/pdf.html#|title=Final apoteotico|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1957|page=7|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
Italian [[Ercole Baldini]] took the lead of the [[1958 Giro d'Italia]] after winning the mountainous, fifteenth stage to Bosco Chiesanuova.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1958 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1958.html |title=1958 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> He won one more stage en route to his overall victory.<ref name="BRI 1958 Giro"/><ref name="1958p1 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1958/06/09/pagina-1/648151/pdf.html#|title=Baldini Gano El Giro Y Poblet La Etapa Y Ademas La Clasificacion Por Puntos|language=Spanish|date=9 June 1958|page=1|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Baldini Wins the Tour, Poblet the Stage, and Ademas the Points Classification|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref><ref name="1958p2 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1958/06/09/pagina-10/1373283/pdf.html#|title=Baldini Gano El Giro|language=Spanish|date=9 June 1958|page=10|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Baldini Wins the Tour|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> The [[1959 Giro d'Italia]] was headlined by the favorites [[Jacques Anquetil]] and Charly Gaul.<ref name="BRI 1959 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1959.html |title=1959 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Anquetil held the lead of the race going into the penultimate stage.<ref name="BRI 1959 Giro"/> Before the stage, Gaul stated openly that he was going to attack on the slopes of the [[Piccolo San Bernardo]] which caused Anquetil to mark him for most of the stage.<ref name="BRI 1959 Giro"/> Gaul stayed true to his word and attacked as the riders made their way up the Piccolo San Bernardo.<ref name="BRI 1959 Giro"/> Anquetil — who had eaten poorly during the stage — was unable to counter his later attacks.<ref name="BRI 1959 Giro"/> Gaul got away, won stage, and gained close to ten minutes on Anquetil that was sufficient enough to win him the event.<ref name="BRI 1959 Giro"/><ref name="1959 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1959/06/08/pagina-7/644341/pdf.html#|title=El luxemburgués Gaul gran vencedor|language=Spanish|date=8 June 1959|page=7|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=The Luxembourish Gaul Big Winner|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
[[File:Jacques Anquetil, Tour de France 1962 (1).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Jacques Anquetil]] was the first French winner of the Giro d'Italia.|alt=A man wearing a cycling jersey while smiling.]] Jacques Anquetil captured the lead of the [[1960 Giro d'Italia]] after dominating the lengthy stage 14 time trial from [[Seregno]] to [[Lecco]].<ref name="BRI 1960 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1960.html |title=1960 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Anquetil's lead shrunk because of bike issues which prevented him from countering attacks while climbing the [[Gavia Pass]] during the penultimate stage.<ref name="BRI 1960 Giro"/> Anquetil retained a twenty-eight second lead that proved to be enough to last to the race's finish, making him the first French winner of the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1960 Giro"/><ref name="1960 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1960/06/10/pagina-6/646830/pdf.html#|title=Jacques Anquetil, hizo frente al peligro de Nencini y fué el vencedor del Giro|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1960|page=6|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Jacques Anquetil, Faced Nencini's Danger and was the Winner of the Giro|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> [[Arnaldo Pambianco]] captured his lone Giro victory after his efforts in a breakaway on the [[1961 Giro d'Italia|1961 edition's]] fourteenth stage gave him the race lead.<ref name="BRI 1961 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1961.html |title=1961 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="1961 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1961/06/12/pagina-9/640018/pdf.html#|title=Ayer terminó en Milan el 44 Giro, con la brillante victoria del italiano Pambianco|language=Spanish|date=12 June 1961|page=9|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=The 44th Giro ended in Milna, with the Brilliant Victory of Italian Pambianco|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
The [[1962 Giro d'Italia|1962]] edition of the Giro d’Italia was marred by severe weather conditions.<ref name="BRI 1962 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1962.html |title=1962 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The fourteenth stage was shortened following a violent storm which prevented the climbing of the last two scheduled mountain passes and the stage finished atop the Passo Rolle.<ref name="BRI 1962 Giro"/> [[Angelino Soler]] won the race's sixteenth stage, with [[Franco Balmamion]] finishing second on the stage and taking the race lead.<ref name="BRI 1962 Giro"/> Balmamion successfully defended the lead all the way to the race's finish in Milan.<ref name="BRI 1962 Giro"/><ref name="1962 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1962/06/10/pagina-8/647399/pdf.html#|title=Balmamion, Vencedor Absoluto Del Giro|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1962|page=8|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Balmamion, Absolute Winner of the Giro|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Balmamion repeated as champion the [[1963 Giro d'Italia|next year]] after gaining the lead after the nineteenth stage that contained six difficult climbs.<ref name="BRI 1963 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1963.html |title=1963 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="1963 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1963/06/10/pagina-8/933887/pdf.html#|title=Termino Bajo La Lluvia|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1963|page=8|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=End in the Rain|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
Jacques Anquetil took the race lead at the [[1964 Giro d'Italia]] after the stage five [[individual time trial]].<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1964 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1964.html |title=1964 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="1964 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1964/06/08/pagina-8/926281/pdf.html#|title=Terminó el "Giro" con la victoria de Jacques Anquetil|language=Spanish|date=8 June 1964|page=8|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=The "Tour" finished with the victory of Jacques Anquetil|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Despite the best attempts of Franco Balmamion and [[Italo Zilioli]], Anquetil managed to keep his lead until the race's conclusion to win his second Giro d'Italia.<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1964 Giro"/> The [[1965 Giro d'Italia]] saw the introduction of the ''[[Cima Coppi]]'' — in honor of [[Fausto Coppi]] — which is the title given to the highest mountain in each Giro and gives more points towards the [[Mountains classification in the Giro d'Italia|mountains classification]] than any other climb.<ref name="BRI 1965 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1965.html |title=1965 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> [[Vittorio Adorni]] won the stage 13 individual time trial and gained a significant time advantage over the rest of the riders.<ref name="BRI 1965 Giro"/> Adorni held on to the race lead for the rest of the race and won his first Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1965 Giro"/>
In [[1966 Giro d'Italia|1966]] the [[Points classification in the Giro d'Italia|points classification]] was introduced, which was to be awarded the most consistent high finishing riders in the peloton, specifically the [[Cycling sprinter|sprinters]].<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1966 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1966.html |title=1966 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Jacques Anquetil came to the race with aspirations to win, but after losing time early on, he decided to ride for his teammate [[Gianni Motta]].<ref name="BRI 1966 Giro"/> With Anquetil's help, Motta rode well through the mountains, gained the lead after the fifteenth leg, and went on to win the event as a whole.<ref name="BRI 1966 Giro"/><ref name="1966 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1966/06/10/pagina-6/939131/pdf.html#|title=Motta definitivo vencedor en Trieste|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1966|page=6|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Motta definitive winner in Trieste|location=[[Trieste]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> In addition, Motta also won the inaugural points classification.<ref name="gazzetta2005"/><ref name="BRI 1966 Giro"/> During the [[1967 Giro d'Italia|1967 edition's]] twentieth stage, [[Felice Gimondi]] attacked on the slopes of the [[Tonale]] and race leader Anquetil was not able to match his move.<ref name="BRI 1967 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1967.html |title=1967 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Upon the stage's conclusion, Gimondi had gained the race lead by over three minutes.<ref name="BRI 1967 Giro"/><ref name="1967 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1967/06/12/pagina-8/929984/pdf.html#|title=Gimondi, vencedor del "Giro" del Cincuentenario|language=Spanish|date=12 June 1967|page=8|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Gimondi, winner of the Fiftieth "Tour" |location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Gimondi raced into Milan the next day and won his first Giro d'Italia victory.<ref name="BRI 1967 Giro"/><ref name="1967 elm final"/>
==1968–1996: Foreign domination==
[[File:Eddy Merckx 1968.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Eddy Merckx]] won the Giro d'Italia a record five times in his career.|alt=A man with short black hair.]] The [[1968 Giro d'Italia]] saw two important firsts: the first tests for drug use and the first prologue.<ref name="BRI 1968 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1968.html |title=1968 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> A total of eight riders tested positive during the Giro.<ref name="BRI 1968 Giro"/> Belgian [[Eddy Merckx]] won his first Giro d'Italia after winning the twelfth stage's finish atop the [[Tre Cime di Lavaredo]] and also regaining the race lead.<ref name="BRI 1968 Giro"/><ref name="1968 final results">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1968/06/13/pagina-18/951543/pdf.html|title=Giro d'Italia|language=Spanish|date=13 June 1968|page=18|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Tour of Italy}}</ref> En route to the overall victory, Merckx won four stages.<ref name="BRI 1968 Giro"/> Merckx returned in [[1969 Giro d'Italia|1969]] and was leading the race after the sixteenth stage that ended in [[Savona]].<ref name="BRI 1969 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1969.html |title=1969 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Merckx tested positive for a banned substance after the stage and was subsequently disqualified from the race; to this day Merckx still proclaims his innocence.<ref name="BRI 1969 Giro"/> [[Felice Gimondi]] took the lead after Merckx's dismissal and held it all the way to the race's conclusion.<ref name="BRI 1969 Giro"/><ref name="1969 final results">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1969/06/09/pagina-20/961100/pdf.html#|title=Esperada Victoria Final Del Italiano Gimondi|language=Spanish|date=9 June 1969|page=20|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Expected Final Victory of Italian Gimondi|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
Merckx came back the [[1970 Giro d'Italia|following year]] to liking of his sponsor.<ref name="BRI 1970 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1970.html |title=1970 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Merckx took the lead after stage five and never relinquished it; he dominated the lengthy stage nine time trial.<ref name="BRI 1970 Giro"/><ref name="1970 final results">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1970/06/08/pagina-30/962217/pdf.html#|title=Merckx Rubrico Su Previsto Triunfo|language=Spanish|date=8 June 1970|page=30|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Merckx Rubric Your Intended Triumph|location=[[Bolzano]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Merckx went on to win the [[1970 Tour de France|Tour de France]] and in doing so became the third rider to win two [[Grand Tour (cycling)|Grand Tours]] in a single calendar year.<ref name="BRI 1970 Giro"/> In [[1971 Giro d'Italia|1971]], reigning champion Merckx decided to ride the [[Critérium du Dauphiné|Critérium du Dauphiné Libéré]] instead.<ref name="BRI 1971 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1971.html |title=1971 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Felice Gimondi lost substantial time early on in the race to put him out of contention, while fellow Italian and teammate [[Gianni Motta]] tested positive for banned substances and was dismissed from the Giro.<ref name="BRI 1971 Giro"/> Swedish cyclist [[Gösta Pettersson]] gained the lead after the race's eighteenth stage and held it all the way to the finish.<ref name="BRI 1971 Giro"/><ref name="1971 final results">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1971/06/11/pagina-17/975989/pdf.html#|title=Gosta Pettersson Gano El "Giro"|language=Spanish|date=11 June 1971|page=17|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Gosta Pettersson wins the "Tour"|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Pettersson became the first Swedish cyclist to win a Grand Tour.<ref name="BRI 1971 Giro"/><ref name="1971 final results"/>
Merckx returned to the Giro in [[1972 Giro d'Italia|1972]] and resumed his domination. He grabbed the lead after a long solo attack during the race's seventh stage and never let go of the lead.<ref name="BRI 1972 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1972.html |title=1972 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="1972 final results">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1972/06/12/pagina-25/980229/pdf.html#|title=Detras de Merckx... ¡Solo Los Españoles!|language=Spanish|date=12 June 1972|page=25|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Behind Merckx...
