Only the Spanish!|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Merckx led the [[1973 Giro d'Italia]] from start to finish; a feat that had not been done since [[Alfredo Binda]] did in [[1927 Giro d'Italia|1927]].<ref name="BRI 1973 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1973.html |title=1973 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="1973 final results">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1973/06/10/pagina-19/981352/pdf.html#|title=Merckx, <<Maglia Rosa>> De Principio A Fin|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1973|page=19|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title= Merckx, <<Pink Jersey>> From Beginning to End|location=[[Trieste]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> [[José Manuel Fuente]] gained the lead early on in [[1974 Giro d'Italia|1974]] and held it all the way up to the Giro's fourteenth stage.<ref name="BRI 1974 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1974.html |title=1974 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Fuente had forgotten to eat properly during the fourteenth stage and suffered because of it; he lost over ten minutes to Merckx.<ref name="BRI 1974 Giro"/> Merckx would go on to win his fifth and final Giro d'Italia by just 12 seconds, joining the likes of Alfredo Binda and [[Fausto Coppi]] as the only five-time winners of the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1974 Giro"/><ref name="1974 final results">{{cite news|url= http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1974/06/09/pagina-21/996408/pdf.html#|title=Quinto Triunfo de Merckx En El "Giro" |language=Spanish|date=9 June 1974|page=21|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Merck’s Fifth win in the "Tour"|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Merckx success continued on into the season as he won the [[1974 Tour de France|Tour de France]] and the [[1974 UCI Road World Championships|men's road race]] at the [[UCI Road World Championships|World Championships]] and became the first rider to complete the [[Triple Crown of Cycling]] – which consists of winning two Grand Tours and the men's road race at the World Championships in one calendar year.<ref name="EM CHOF TC S">{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclinghalloffame.com/riders/rider_bio.asp?rider_id=1 |title=Rider Biographies - Eddy Merckx |work=Cycling Hall of Fame.com |publisher=Cycling Hall of Fame.com |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref>
With the absence of Merckx from the [[1975 Giro d'Italia|1975 edition]] due to illness, the competition increased between the other riders.<ref name="BRI 1975 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1975.html |title=1975 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> [[Fausto Bertoglio]] and [[Francisco Galdós]] battled during the latter half of the race.<ref name="BRI 1975 Giro"/> The final stage of the race had a summit finish on the [[Passo dello Stelvio]] where Bertoglio fended off the attacks of Galdós to seal his overall victory.<ref name="BRI 1975 Giro"/><ref name="1975 final results">{{cite news|url= http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1975/06/08/pagina-19/1005409/pdf.html# |title= Bertoglio Se Adjudico El "Giro"|language=Spanish|date=8 June 1975|page=19|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Bertoglio was awarded the "Tour"|location=[[Stelvio Pass]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> [[Johan de Muynck]] was in the lead of the [[1976 Giro d'Italia]] when he crashed during the twentieth stage.<ref name="BRI 1976 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1976.html |title=1976 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Muynck's injuries prevented him from performing well in the next day's [[individual time trial]].<ref name="BRI 1976 Giro"/> Felice Gimondi capitalized on Muynck's woes and took the lead on the final day of racing and went on to win his second Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1976 Giro"/><ref name="1976 final results">{{cite news|url= http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1976/06/13/pagina-12/1009778/pdf.html#|title=Gimondi (34 Años) Se Impuso Por Tercera Vez|language=Spanish|date=13 June 1976|page=12|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=Gimondi (34 years) was Imposed for Third Time|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> This was the last Giro that Merckx raced; he finished eighth overall.<ref name="BRI 1976 Giro"/>
[[File:Bernard Hinault (1982).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Bernard Hinault]] won Giro d'Italia three times in his career.|alt=A man smiling.]] [[Freddy Maertens]] and [[Francesco Moser]] dominated the early portion of the [[1977 Giro d'Italia]].<ref name="BRI 1977 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1977.html |title=1977 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Belgian [[Michel Pollentier]] took the lead from Moser when the race hit the high mountains near the end of the race. Pollentier went on to win the penultimate stage en route to his lone Grand Tour victory of his career.<ref name="BRI 1977 Giro"/><ref name="1977 final results">{{cite news|url= http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1977/06/13/pagina-30/1026802/pdf.html#|title=El vencedor: <<Quise retirarme y ya ven..>>|language=Spanish|date=13 June 1976|page=30|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|trans-title=The winner: << I wanted to retire and you see .. >>|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Johan de Muynck first grabbed the lead of the [[1978 Giro d'Italia]] after escaping during the third stage and soloing to victory.<ref name="BRI 1978 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1978.html |title=1978 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> He then successfully defended his slim lead throughout the rest of the race and won the Giro.<ref name="BRI 1978 Giro"/><ref name="78 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1978/05/29/pagina-31/1024498/pdf.html#|title=De Muynck, al libro de oro del "Giro"|language=Spanish|date=29 May 1978|page=31|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=De Muynck, the Golden Book "Tour"|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> The [[1979 Giro d'Italia|1979 edition]] featured less climbing than normal and a total of five time trials.<ref name="BRI 1979 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1979.html |title=1979 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Francesco Moser grabbed the early lead of the race after winning the first two time trials of the race.<ref name="BRI 1979 Giro"/> [[Giuseppe Saronni]] took the lead after the third time trial which ended in [[San Marino]].<ref name="BRI 1979 Giro"/> Saronni then rode into Milan with over a two-minute lead over Moser to win the Giro.<ref name="BRI 1979 Giro"/><ref name="79 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1979/06/07/pagina-23/1045781/pdf.html#|title=Saronni Le Robo <<Su>> <<Giro>> A Moser|language=Spanish|date=7 June 1979|page=23|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Saronni Stole <<his>> <<Tour>> from Moser|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
[[Bernard Hinault]]'s Giro d'Italia was in [[1980 Giro d'Italia|1980]].<ref name="BRI 1980 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1980.html |title=1980 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Up until the twentieth stage, the race was being dominated by the Italian competitors.<ref name="BRI 1980 Giro"/> During the twentieth stage, Hinault and teammate [[Jean-René Bernaudeau]] distanced themselves from the general classification contenders on the slopes of the [[Passo dello Stelvio]] and rode into [[Sondrio]] for the stage win.<ref name="BRI 1980 Giro"/> Bernaudeau won the stage, but Hinault took a sizable lead over the rest of the field – which he then held to the race's conclusion in [[Milan]].<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1980 Giro"/><ref name="80 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1980/06/09/pagina-32/1056778/pdf.html#|title=Hinault Apacento Sus Ovejas|language=Spanish|date=9 June 1980|page=32|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Hinault Grazed His Sheep}}</ref> The [[1981 Giro d'Italia]] was hotly contested, with four riders being 30 seconds apart after twenty days of racing.<ref name="BRI 1981 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1981.html |title=1981 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Stage 20 saw the finish atop the [[Tre Cime di Lavaredo]].<ref name="BRI 1981 Giro"/> [[Giovanni Battaglin]] took the lead by almost a minute over the second place rider after doing well on the climb of the Lavaredo.<ref name="BRI 1981 Giro"/><ref name="81 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1981/06/08/pagina-30/1069292/pdf.html#|title=Battaglin: Despues de la <<Vuelta>>... El <<Giro>>|language=Spanish|date=8 June 1981|page=30|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Battaglin: After the <<Vuelta>>... the <<Giro>>|location=[[Verona]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Battaglin won the Giro after putting in a solid performance in the race's final stage, an individual time trial.<ref name="BRI 1981 Giro"/><ref name="81 elm final"/>
Bernard Hinault returned to the Giro in [[1982 Giro d'Italia|1982]].<ref name="BRI 1982 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1982.html |title=1982 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Hinault dominated the race with stage wins in every time trial stage and stage wins atop the [[Campitello Matese]] and the [[Montecampione]] en route to the overall victory.<ref name="BRI 1982 Giro"/><ref name="82 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1982/06/07/pagina-32/1417587/pdf.html#|title=Hinault: La Vida En Rosa|language=Spanish|date=7 June 1982|page=32|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Hinault: the Life in Rose|location=[[Turin]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Hinault would go on to win the [[1982 Tour de France|Tour de France]] that year as well and complete the coveted Giro-Tour double.<ref name="BRI 1982 Giro"/> The [[1983 Giro d'Italia]] featured few hard stages in the mountains and four time trials.<ref name="BRI 1983 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1983.html |title=1983 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The winner of the race, Giuseppe Saronni, gained the lead after the race's seventh stage that finished in [[Salerno]].<ref name="BRI 1983 Giro"/> From there, Saronni won two more stages and successfully guarded his lead all the way to Milan to win his second Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1983 Giro"/><ref name="83 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1983/06/06/pagina-32/1098624/pdf.html#|title=Saronni, La Vida En Rosa|language=Spanish|date=6 June 1983|page=32|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Saronni, the Life in Rose|location=[[Udine]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
The [[1984 Giro d'Italia]] was a battle between Italian Francesco Moser and Frenchman [[Laurent Fignon]].<ref name="BRI 1984 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1984.html |title=1984 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Moser was leading the race up until the mountainous stage twentieth stage that finished in [[Arabba]].<ref name="BRI 1984 Giro"/> Fignon took the lead after riding into Arabba over two minutes ahead of Moser.<ref name="BRI 1984 Giro"/> Moser dashed through the course setting a blistering pace on the roads, he won the stage and the Giro due to his performance in the final stage.<ref name="BRI 1984 Giro"/><ref name="84 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1984/06/11/pagina-28/1103579/pdf.html#|title=Moser: La Fuerza Destino|language=Spanish|date=11 June 1984|page=28|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Moser: The Target Strength|location=[[Verona]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Bernard Hinault raced the Giro again in [[1985 Giro d'Italia|1985]].<ref name="BRI 1985 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1985.html |title=1985 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The race was led early on by Italian [[Roberto Visentini]].<ref name="BRI 1985 Giro"/> However, after the stage twelve time trial, Hinault was in control of the race and went to win his third Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1985 Giro"/><ref name="85 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1985/06/10/pagina-34/1120026/pdf.html|title=Hinault: Tres Vidas En Rosa|language=Spanish|date=10 June 1985|page=34|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Hinault: Three Lives In Pink|location=[[Lucca]], [[Italy]]}}</ref>
[[File:Andy HAMPSTEN.jpg|thumb|left|[[Andrew Hampsten]] became the first non-European to win the Giro d'Italia in [[1988 Giro d'Italia|1988]].|alt=A man wearing a cycling uniform while riding a bike and preparing to turn.]] Giuseppe Saronni led the [[1986 Giro d'Italia]] for the majority of the race before losing it to Roberto Visentini in the [[Alps]].<ref name="BRI 1986 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1986.html |title=1986 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Visentini then fought off attacks from the challengers in the [[Dolomites]] en route to his first Giro d'Italia general classification victory.<ref name="BRI 1986 Giro"/><ref name="86 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1986/06/03/pagina-50/1137689/pdf.html#|title=Visentini: La Vida En Rosa|language=Spanish|date=3 June 1986|page=50|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Visentini: the Life in Rose|location=[[Merano]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> The [[1987 Giro d'Italia|1987 edition]] was highlighted by the controversy between {{ct|CAR|1987}}'s two general classification riders Roberto Visentini and [[Stephen Roche]].<ref name="BRI 1987 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1987.html |title=1987 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Roche led the race early on but lost the lead to Visentini after crashing during the thirteenth stage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1987/06/05/pagina-45/1151604/pdf.html|title=Visentini: La Contrarreloj Consagra|language=Spanish|date=5 June 1987|page=43|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Visentini: The Time Trial consecrates}}</ref> Roche attacked on the race's mountainous fifteenth stage despite orders from Carrera team management not to.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eugenio Capodacqua |language=Italian |date=10 May 2007 |url=http://www.repubblica.it/2007/05/speciale/altri/2007giroditalia/storia-3/storia-3.html |title=La storia del Giro d'Italia |publisher=[[La Repubblica]] |accessdate=27 December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224103726/http://www.repubblica.it/2007/05/speciale/altri/2007giroditalia/storia-3/storia-3.html |archivedate=24 December 2007 |deadurl=no |trans-title=The history of the Tour of Italy |df= }}</ref> Roche took the lead and wound up winning the Giro.<ref name="BRI 1987 Giro"/> Roche's success would not stop there during the 1987 season, he would go on to win the [[1987 Tour de France|Tour de France]] and the [[1987 UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race|men's road race]] at the World Championships to complete the Triple Crown of Cycling.<ref name="BRI 1987 Giro"/>
The [[1988 Giro d'Italia]] is remembered for the fourteenth stage that contained very poor weather throughout the stage and most notably on the slopes of the [[Passo di Gavia]].<ref name="velonews interview">{{cite news|author=John Wilcockson|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2012/05/news/from-the-pages-of-velo-hampstens-giro-i-was-so-happy-to-survive_221346|title=From the pages of Velo: Hampsten’s Giro: ‘I was so happy to survive’|date=27 May 2012|page=1 |work=VeloNews|publisher=Competitor Group, Inc|accessdate=23 June 2012}}</ref> [[Franco Chioccioli]] led the race at the start of the fabled fourteenth stage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1988/06/05/pagina-36/1181878/pdf.html|title=Rominger: Revancha A Lo Campeon|language=Spanish|date=5 June 1988|page=36|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Rominger: Revenge To The Champion}}</ref> On the slopes of the Gavia, [[Andrew Hampsten]] and [[Erik Breukink]] rode away from their fellow riders; Breukink would go on to win the stage, but Hampsten would take the overall lead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/features/giro-ditalia-anglophone-invasion |title=Giro d'Italia: Anglophone Invasion |author=Peter Hymas |date=4 May 2011|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref> Hampsten went on to win the race and became the first non-European to win the Giro d'Italia.<ref>{{cite news|author=Samuel Abt|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/13/sports/us-cyclist-captures-tour-of-italy.html|title=U.S. Cyclist Captures Tour of Italy|date=13 June 1988|page=22|work=The New York Times|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref>
Dutchman Erik Breukink gained the lead of the [[1989 Giro d'Italia]] after winning the stage 10 individual time trial.<ref name="BRI 1989 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1989.html |title=1989 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Breukink lost the lead after the fourteenth stage that contained five major passes.<ref name="BRI 1989 Giro"/> The Frenchman Laurent Fignon took the lead of the race from Breukink and then held it all the way to the finish in [[Florence]].<ref name="larousse1"/><ref name="BRI 1989 Giro"/><ref name="89 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1989/06/12/pagina-72/1196804/pdf.html#|title=A Golpe de Fignon|language=Spanish|date=12 June 1989|page=72|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=A Fignon Coup|location=[[Florence]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> This was also the year the [[Intergiro classification in the Giro d'Italia|intergiro classification]] was introduced to the Giro d'Italia – the calculation for the intergiro is similar to that of the general classification, in each stage there is a midway point that the riders pass through a point and where their time is stopped and then totaled up after each stage.<ref name="demystified">{{cite web|author=Laura Weislo|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2008/giro08/?id=/features/2008/giro_classifications08|title=Giro d'Italia classifications demystified|date=13 May 2008|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> Jure Pavlič was the first winner of the intergiro classification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2008/giro08/?id=history |title=Past winners |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=1 June 2008 |accessdate=19 July 2012}}</ref> [[Gianni Bugno]] dominated the [[1990 Giro d'Italia|1990 edition]] after gaining the lead after the first stage.<ref name="BRI 1990 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1990.html |title=1990 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref name="90 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1990/06/07/pagina-46/1219757/pdf.html|title=El corazón en un "Bugno"|language=Spanish|date=7 June 1990|page=48|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=The heart in "Bugno"|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Bugno led the race from start to finish – a feat that had only been done three times before in the history of the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1990 Giro"/><ref name="90 elm final"/>
[[File:Miguel Indurain en la Vuelta a Castilla y León 2009.jpg|thumb|[[Miguel Indurain]] was the first Spanish rider to win the Giro d'Italia.|alt=A man looking at the camera while wearing a suit.]] Franco Chioccioli reigned supreme at the [[1991 Giro d'Italia]].<ref name="BRI 1991 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1991.html |title=1991 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Chioccioli led the race for all but two stages.<ref name="BRI 1991 Giro"/> He cemented his lead and the eventual overall victory by winning the seventeenth stage that contained a summit finish on the [[Passo Pordoi]] and winning the penultimate stage which was an individual time trial.<ref name="BRI 1991 Giro"/> [[Miguel Indurain]] became the first Spanish rider to win the Giro d'Italia in [[1992 Giro d'Italia|1992]]<ref name="BRI 1992 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1992.html |title=1992 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Indurain first gained the lead of the race after the hilly third stage that led into [[Arrezo]] and then held it all the way to the finish in Milan.<ref name="BRI 1992 Giro"/> He separated himself from his competitors during the race's two individual time trials, both of which he won.<ref name="BRI 1992 Giro"/> Indurain would go on to ride the [[1992 Tour de France|Tour de France]] in July and win it, and in doing so completed the rare Giro-Tour double.<ref name="BRI 1992 Giro"/>
Indurain returned in [[1993 Giro d'Italia|1993]] to defend his crown.<ref name="BRI 1993 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1993.html |title=1993 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> The only rider that could compete with Indurain was the Latvian [[Piotr Ugrumov]], who attacked Indurain repeatedly throughout the race.<ref name="BRI 1993 Giro"/> Indurain won two stages – both time trials – en route to his second Giro d'Italia victory.<ref name="BRI 1993 Giro"/> He would go on to complete the Giro-Tour double for the second consecutive year, a feat which had never been accomplished before.<ref name="BRI 1993 Giro"/> The [[1994 Giro d'Italia]] saw Russian [[Evgeni Berzin]] gain the overall lead after winning the fourth stage, featuring a summit finish on Campitello Matese.<ref name="BRI 1994 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1994.html |title=1994 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Berzin consolidated his lead with victories in the race's final two time trials en route to the overall victory. In doing so he spoiled Indurain's hopes for a three peat.<ref name="BRI 1994 Giro"/>
[[Tony Rominger]] came to the [[1995 Giro d'Italia]] in great form.<ref name="BRI 1995 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1995.html |title=1995 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Rominger gained the lead after the stage two time trial and never gave it up.<ref name="BRI 1995 Giro"/> His opposition came from the returning champion Berzin and teammate Piotr Ugrumov who attacked each other repeatedly, which greatly hurt their chances.<ref name="BRI 1995 Giro"/> In addition to the general classification, Rominger also won the points and intergiro classifications.<ref name="BRI 1995 Giro"/> The [[1996 Giro d'Italia]] celebrated the centenary of the founding of ''[[La Gazzetta dello Sport]]'' by holding the first three stages in the Greek capital of [[Athens]].<ref name="BRI 1996 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1996.html |title=1996 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Eventual winner [[Pavel Tonkov]] first gained the race lead after the mountainous thirteenth stage that ended in [[Prato Nevoso]].<ref name="BRI 1996 Giro"/> Tonkov lost his slim lead to the Spaniard [[Abraham Olano]] for a two-stage period, before regaining it after stage 21, which contained five climbs of high severity.<ref name="BRI 1996 Giro"/> Tonkov rode into Milan the next day winner of the Giro d'Italia.<ref name="BRI 1996 Giro"/>
==1997–2007: Italians resume conquest==
[[File:Marco Pantani.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Marco Pantani]] completed the Giro-Tour double in 1998.|alt=A cyclist unzipping his yellow cycling jersey.]] [[Pavel Tonkov]] returned to the Giro in [[1997 Giro d'Italia|1997]] with ambitions of repeating as winner.<ref name="BRI 1997 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1997.html |title=1997 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Tonkov first led the race after winning the stage three time trial and up until the fourteenth stage's conclusion.<ref name="BRI 1997 Giro"/> During the fourteenth stage, Italian [[Ivan Gotti]] attacked and soloed his way to take the stage win in [[Breuil-Cervinia]] and the race lead.<ref name="BRI 1997 Giro"/> Gotti extended his lead after performing well in the mountainous nineteenth stage and went on to win the Giro three days later.<ref name="BRI 1997 Giro"/><ref name="97 elm final">{{cite news|url=http://hemeroteca.mundodeportivo.com/preview/1997/06/09/pagina-52/1383072/pdf.html|title=Ivan Gotti, primer italiano que gana el Giro desde 1991|language=Spanish|date=9 June 1997|page=52|newspaper=El Mundo Deportivo|accessdate=27 May 2012|format=PDF|trans-title=Ivan Gotti, the first Italian to win the Giro since 1991|location=[[Milan]], [[Italy]]}}</ref> Swiss rider [[Alex Zülle]] was the first rider to lead the [[1998 Giro d'Italia]] and he led for the most part of the race.<ref name="BRI 1998 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1998.html |title=1998 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Zülle was leading the race as it entered the [[Dolomites]].<ref name="BRI 1998 Giro"/> Italians [[Giuseppe Guerini]] and [[Marco Pantani]] were at the head of the race during the race's mountainous seventeenth stage; the two riders worked together to get to the stage finish in [[Selva di Val Gardena]].<ref name="BRI 1998 Giro"/> Guerini won the stage while Pantani took the overall lead.<ref name="BRI 1998 Giro"/> Pantani went on to win the Giro and subsequently the [[1998 Tour de France]], thus completing the rare feat of winning the Giro d'Italia and the Tour de France in the same calendar year.<ref name="BRI 1998 Giro"/>
Pantani returned to the Giro in [[1999 Giro d'Italia|1999]] while in peak physical form.<ref name="BRI 1999 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro1999.html |title=1999 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Pantani gained the lead after the race's fourteenth stage and as the race hit the high mountains, he extended his lead with three stage wins.<ref name="BRI 1999 Giro"/> On the morning of the twentieth stage, Pantani was dismissed from the Giro after having [[hematocrit]] levels above 50%.<ref name="BRI 1999 Giro"/> 1997 victor Ivan Gotti, who was second place at the time, subsequently took the lead and wound up winning the Giro for the second time in his career.<ref name="BRI 1999 Giro"/> [[Francesco Casagrande]] took the lead in the [[2000 Giro d'Italia]] after a long solo attack during the race's ninth stage.<ref name="BRI 2000 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro2000.html |title=2000 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Fatigue set in with Casagrande as the race wore on and on the penultimate stage he lost the lead, and ultimately the Giro, to [[Stefano Garzelli]].<ref name="BRI 2000 Giro"/>
[[Dario Frigo]] took the lead in the [[2001 Giro d'Italia]] after the race's fourth stage.<ref name="BRI 2001 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro2001.html |title=2001 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Frigo defended the lead until the thirteenth stage, when the race went over some major passes in the [[Dolomites]].<ref name="BRI 2001 Giro"/> During the thirteenth stage, [[Gilberto Simoni]] attacked and his labor bore fruits as he took the race leader's ''maglia rosa'' when the stage was over.<ref name="BRI 2001 Giro"/> Frigo gained some time back in the stage fifteen time trial, but it wasn't enough to overcome Simoni's lead.<ref name="BRI 2001 Giro"/> Simoni went on to win the Giro d'Italia by a wide margin after Frigo's withdrawal.<ref name="BRI 2001 Giro"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/results/2001/giro01/results/stage20.shtml |title=Simoni wins in pink |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=9 June 2000|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Jeff Jones}}</ref> Stefano Garzelli took the early lead after winning the [[2002 Giro d'Italia]]'s second stage, but soon tested positive for [[probenecid]] – a banned substance – and was forced to leave the Giro.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2002/giro02/?id=results/stage6 |title=After Garzelli non-negative, hard-man Heppner takes Giro lead |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=18 May 2002|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2002/giro02/?id=results/stage9 |title=Magnificent Mario spreads his wings again |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=21 May 2002|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Jeff Jones}}</ref> In the final major mountain stage of the race, stage seventeen, [[Paolo Savoldelli]] attacked with around nine kilometers to go in the stage and managed to take the lead and go on to win the Giro.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2002/giro02/?id=results/stage17 |title=Savoldelli flies into Maglia Rosa while Evans cracks |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=30 May 2002|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2002/giro02/?id=results/stage20 |title=Cipollini leads them home in Milan |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=2 June 2002|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Jeff Jones}}</ref>
[[File:Damiano Cunego GiroItalia2006.jpg|upright|thumb|[[Damiano Cunego]] won the Giro in [[2004 Giro d'Italia|2004]].|alt=A man signing autographs while wearing a pink and blue cycling jersey.]] Alessandro Petacchi was the first rider to lead the [[2003 Giro d'Italia]] after winning the opening stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2003/giro03/?id=results/stage1 |title=Big breakthrough win for Petacchi |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=10 May 2003|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref> Petacchi lost the lead to Stefano Garzelli after he won the stage seven summit finish on the [[Monte Terminillo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2003/giro03/?id=results/stage7 |title=Selection on Terminillo shakes up Giro |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=17 May 2003|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref> Garzelli then lost the lead to Gilberto Simoni after the tenth stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2003/giro03/?id=results/stage10 |title=Audacious Simoni grabs Maglia Rosa by 2 |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=20 May 2003|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref> Simoni went on to win the Giro after expanding his lead through stage wins on the [[Monte Zoncolan]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2003/giro03/?id=results/stage12 |title=Ecco Fatto: Simoni reigns on Zoncolan |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=22 May 2003|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref> and the [[Alpe di Pampeago]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2003/giro03/?id=results/stage14 |title=Gibo flies at Pampeago; Garzelli just won't crack |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=24 May 2003|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2003/giro03/?id=results/stage21 |title=Gontchar takes finale; Simoni home in pink|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date= 1 June 2003|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Chris Henry}}</ref> The [[2004 Giro d'Italia]] saw a battle between [[Damiano Cunego]], [[Serhiy Honchar]], and Gilberto Simoni.<ref name="CyclingNews Stage 20 Recap & Final Standings">{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2004/giro04/?id=results/stage20 |title=The 2004 Giro: A tale of two Italians|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=30 May 2004|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Chris Henry}}</ref> Simoni gained the lead after the third stage and held it to the seventh stage where he lost it to Cunego.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2004/giro04/?id=results/stage7 |title=Kid Cunego flies like an eagle to Maglia Rosa |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=15 May 2004|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Chris Henry}}</ref> Cunego held the lead until the lengthy stage twelve individual time trial when [[Yaroslav Popovych]] took the lead.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2004/giro04/?id=results/stage13 |title=Popovych pounds to Maglia Rosa in Trieste|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=22 May 2004|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Chris Henry}}</ref> Cunego regained the lead after the sixteenth stage and went on to win the race, while fellow Italian Alessandro Petacchi won nine out of the 21 stages.<ref name="CyclingNews Stage 20 Recap & Final Standings"/>
The [[2005 Giro d'Italia]] saw the race lead change hands multiple times within the first week of racing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro2005.html |title=2005 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> [[Ivan Basso]] gained the lead after the eleventh stage, which finished in [[Zoldo Alto]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2005/giro05/?id=results/giro0511 |title=Basso busts Giro wide open on first mountain stage and takes maglia rosa |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=19 May 2005|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref> Two days later, Paolo Savoldelli gained the lead after the thirteenth stage that finish in [[Urtijëi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2005/giro05/?id=results/giro0513 |title=Il Falco flies again: super Savoldelli soars to maglia rosa|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=21 May 2005|accessdate=20 June 2013|author=Tim Maloney}}</ref> Savoldelli went on to win his second Giro d'Italia while fending off the attacks of Gilberto Simoni and [[José Rujano]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2005//giro05/?id=results/giro0520 |title=Salvation for Savoldelli|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=29 May 2005|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Anthony Tan}}</ref> [[Ivan Basso]] won the [[2006 Giro d'Italia]] in a convincing fashion.<ref name="BRI 2006 Giro">{{cite web|url=http://bikeraceinfo.com/giro/giro2006.html |title=2006 Giro d'Italia |work= Bike Race Info |publisher=Dog Ear Publishing |last1=McGann |first1=Bill |last2=McGann |first2=Carol |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Basso gained the lead after winning the race's eighth stage that featured a summit finish on the Passo Lanciano.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2006//giro06/?id=results/giro068 |title=Not too terrible: Ivan Basso takes stage, maglia rosa on Maielletta |work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=28 May 2006|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Tim Maloney}}</ref> He won two more stages after taking the lead of the race en route to his overall victory.<ref name="BRI 2006 Giro"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2006/stage-21/results |title="Seven key moments"; Mission 1 of 2 complete|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited |date=28 May 2006|accessdate=20 June 2013|author= Anthony Tan}}</ref>
The race leader's pink jersey changed hands five times in the first week of racing in the [[2007 Giro d'Italia]]. [[Andrea Noè]] took the lead away from [[Marco Pinotti]] after the race's tenth stage.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gregor Brown and Tim Maloney|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2007/giro07/?id=results/giro0710|title=Piepoli takes Santuario win – Noè new ''Rosa''|date=22 May 2007|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> Noè lost the lead to Danilo Di Luca after he won the twelfth stage into [[Briançon]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Gregor Brown and Tim Maloney|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2007//giro07/?id=results/giro0712|title=Di Luca takes day: ''Rosa'' and stage|date=24 May 2007|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> Di Luca was not seriously challenged after taking the race lead in stage 12, and comfortably won the Giro in Milan with a two-minute gap over Schleck in second.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gregor Brown and Tim Maloney|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2007/giro07/?id=results/giro0721|title=Petacchi reigns sprint king – Di Luca secures Giro win|date=3 June 2007|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref>
==2008–2018: Recent years==
[[File:Alberto Contador Giro.jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Alberto Contador]] won the [[2011 Giro d'Italia]] before being stripped of his title after being found guilty of taking banned substances.|alt=A man wearing a pink jersey and black shorts while holding a golden trophy.]] The [[2008 Giro d'Italia]] was led for many days by [[Giovanni Visconti (cyclist)|Giovanni Visconti]] who had gained the lead after participating in a breakaway.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shane Stokes and Gregor Brown|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2008/giro08/?id=results/giro086|title=Priamo nets first Giro win while Visconti lands big catch |date=15 May 2008|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> Eventual winner [[Alberto Contador]] first took the lead of the race after the second mountain stage, to [[Marmolada]], by finishing nearly fifteen minutes ahead of previous race leader [[Gabriele Bosisio]] – who had just gained the lead the stage before.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gregor Brown and Bjorn Haake|url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2008/giro08/?id=results/giro0815|title=Dolomite delight: Italy's Sella doubles, Contador in ''maglia rosa''|date=25 May 2008|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> In the race's final week, Contador faced stern challenges from Riccò and defending Giro champion [[Danilo Di Luca]]; however, their efforts bore no fruits as Contador went on to win the race.<ref name="stage21"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Gregor Brown and Bjorn Haake |url=http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2008/giro08/?id=results/giro0821 |title=Hola! Contador conquers second Grand Tour |date=1 June 2008 |work=Cycling News |publisher=Future Publishing Limited |accessdate=20 June 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091213161517/http://autobus.cyclingnews.com/road/2008/giro08/?id=results%2Fgiro0821 |archivedate=13 December 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Russian [[Denis Menchov]] won the [[2009 Giro d'Italia|2009]] centennial edition of the Giro, after having taken the lead in a long time trial in stage 12, and defended it vigorously against [[Glossary of bicycling#A|attacks]] from his closest challenger, [[Danilo Di Luca]], during the mountain stages of the final week.<ref>{{cite news|author=Brendan Gallagher|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/cycling/5417780/Denis-Menchov-wins-Giro-dItalia.html|title=Denis Menchov wins Giro d'Italia|date=31 May 2009|work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |accessdate=20 June 2013| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090606060501/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/cycling/5417780/Denis-Menchov-wins-Giro-dItalia.html| archivedate= 6 June 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Di Luca came in second, 41 seconds behind the winner, and won the [[points classification in the Giro d'Italia|points classification]]. Subsequent to the Giro, both he and third-place finisher [[Franco Pellizotti]] became embroiled in doping scandals, were given bans, and had their results stripped.<ref name="dilucatests">{{cite web|author=Cyclingnews |url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/di-luca-positive-for-cera-in-giro|title=Di Luca positive for CERA in Giro|date=22 July 2009|work=Cycling News |publisher=Future Publishing Limited |accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=http://sports.espn.go.com/oly/cycling/news/story?id=6192949|title=Franco Pellizotti found guilty of doping|date=8 March 2011|work=[[ESPN]].com |publisher=ESPN Internet Ventures |accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref>
The [[2010 Giro d'Italia]] saw the lead change hands eight times during the race. Spanish rider [[David Arroyo]] was leading the race as it headed into the final mountain stages of the race. Arroyo lost the race lead to [[Ivan Basso]] after the nineteenth stage where he lost over three minutes to Basso.<ref>{{cite web|author=Cycling News|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/93rd-giro-ditalia-gt/stage-19/results|title=Basso charges into pink with Mortirolo attack|date=28 May 2010|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100620033217/http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/93rd-giro-ditalia-gt/stage-19/results| archivedate= 20 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Basso fended off attacks and performed adequately in the final time trial to secure his second Giro d'Italia victory.<ref name="stage21">{{cite web|author=Stephen Farrand|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/93rd-giro-ditalia-gt/stage-21/results|title=Basso wins Giro d'Italia|date=30 May 2010|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100623042628/http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/93rd-giro-ditalia-gt/stage-21/results| archivedate= 23 June 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Alberto Contador returned to the Giro in [[2011 Giro d'Italia|2011]] and was seen as the favorite for the overall victory on what many saw as a very difficult course.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jeremy Inson|agency=[[Associated Press]]|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/cycling/2011-05-05-alberto-contador-giro-favorite_N.htm|title=Alberto Contador is Giro favorite despite doping probe|date=15 May 2011|work=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Agence France Presse|AFP]]|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2011/05/news/alberto-contador-starts-as-top-contender-for-giro-ditalia-crown_171251|title=Alberto Contador starts as top contender for Giro d’Italia crown|date=6 May 2011|work=VeloNews|publisher=Competitor Group, Inc.|accessdate=30 June 2011}}</ref>
On stage 3 of the 2011 Giro d' Italia, [[Wouter Weylandt]] had a fatal crash. The next stage was neutralized, with his [[Trek–Segafredo (men's team)|Leopard Trek]] team and friend [[Tyler Farrar]] allowed to pass the finish line first.
Contador assumed the race lead after winning the ninth stage to [[Mount Etna]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Ryan|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/contador-the-giro-has-just-started|title=Contador: the Giro has just started|date=15 May 2011|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> Contador continued to increase his advantage by riding well in the remaining stages and winning the stage 16 individual time trial, which allowed him to win his second Giro d'Italia championship.<ref>{{cite web|author=Barry Ryan|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2011/stage-21/results|title=Contador claims second Giro d'Italia victory|date=29 May 2011|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref> Contador raced the 2011 Giro despite having an ongoing trial about his possible use of [[clenbuterol]], a banned substance.<ref>{{cite web|author=Cycling News|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/alberto-contador-tests-positive-for-clenbuterol|title=Alberto Contador tests positive for clenbuterol|date=30 September 2010|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|accessdate=30 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110714013253/http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/alberto-contador-tests-positive-for-clenbuterol| archivedate= 14 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 6 February 2012 the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] decided that Contador should lose his [[2010 Tour de France]] title and his results since that race, which included his Giro victory in May 2011, and receive a two-year ban.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/news/cas-sanction-contador-with-two-year-ban-in-clenbuterol-case|title=CAS sanctions Contador with two year ban in clenbutorol case|date=6 February 2012|accessdate=6 February 2012|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|work=Cycling News}}</ref> After Contador's conviction, runner up [[Michele Scarponi]] was then delegated the overall victory.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shane Stokes|url=http://www.velonation.com/News/ID/10895/Confirmed-Contador-handed-two-year-doping-ban-loses-2010-Tour-title.aspx|title=Confirmed: Contador handed two year doping ban, loses 2010 Tour title|date=6 February 2012|work=VeloNation|publisher=VeloNation LLC|accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref>
The [[2012 Giro d'Italia]] saw a battle between Canadian [[Ryder Hesjedal]] and Spaniard [[Joaquim Rodríguez]]. Hesjedal first took the lead after finishing well on the seventh stage that featured a summit finish to [[Rocca di Cambio]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2012/stage-7/results|title=Tiralongo wins into Rocca di Cambio|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|date=12 May 2012|accessdate=12 May 2012|first=Susan|last=Westemeyer}}</ref> Rodríguez snagged a narrow lead over Hesjedal after winning the tenth stage into [[Assisi]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2012/stage-10/results|title=Rodriguez wins Giro stage into Assisi|author=Cycling News|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|date=15 May 2012|accessdate=15 May 2012}}</ref> Hesjedal regained the lead after the mountainous fourteenth stage;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2012/stage-14/results|title=Amador climbs to Giro d'Italia stage 14 victory|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|date=19 May 2012|accessdate=20 May 2012|first=Susan|last=Westemeyer}}</ref> however, Rodríguez took it back the next day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.velonation.com/News/ID/11917/Giro-dItalia-Heroic-Matteo-Rabottini-wins-on-the-Pian-dei-Resinelli-after-day-long-attack.aspx|title=Heroic Matteo Rabottini wins on the Pian dei Resinelli after day-long attack|first=Ben|last=Atkins|work=VeloNation|publisher=VeloNation LLC|date=20 May 2012|accessdate=20 May 2012}}</ref> Rodríguez held that lead all the way to the final stage, which he came into with a 31-second buffer over Hesjedal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2012/stage-20/results|title=De Gendt wins Giro d'Italia penultimate stage atop the Stelvio|first=Susan|last=Westemeyer|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|date=26 May 2012|accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> Hesjedal rode and manage to finish with a time 47 seconds better than Rodríguez, giving him the overall victory in the Giro.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cyclingnews.com/races/giro-ditalia-2012/stage-21/results|title=Ryder Hesjedal wins the Giro d'Italia|first=Peter|last=Cossins|work=Cycling News|publisher=Future Publishing Limited|date=27 May 2012|accessdate=27 May 2012}}</ref> In [[2013 Giro d'Italia|2013]] [[Vincenzo Nibali]] took the lead after the race's eighth stage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.velonation.com/News/ID/14550/Giro-dItalia-Nibali-takes-pink-in-Saltara-time-trial-as-Dowsett-takes-his-maiden-win.aspx|first=Ben|last=Atkins|title=Nibali takes pink in Saltara time trial as Dowsett takes his maiden win|work=VeloNation|publisher=VeloNation LLC|date=11 May 2013|accessdate=12 May 2013}}</ref> Nibali would go on to win the race after he expanded his lead through performing well in the early mountain stages and winning both the stage 18 individual time trial and the penultimate stage of the race.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://velonews.competitor.com/2013/05/news/nibali-wins-stage-18-time-trial-at-2013-giro-ditalia_288345|title=Nibali wins stage 18 time trial at 2013 Giro d'Italia|work=VeloNews|publisher=[[Competitor Group, Inc.]]|author=VeloNews.com|date=23 May 2013|accessdate=24 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.velonation.com/News/ID/14646/Giro-dItalia-Vincenzo-Nibali-attacks-through-the-stage-20-blizzard-to-win-on-the-Tre-Cime.aspx|title=Vincenzo Nibali attacks through the stage 20 blizzard to win on the Tre Cime|first=Ben|last=Atkins|work=VeloNation|publisher=VeloNation LLC|date=25 May 2013|accessdate=26 May 2013}}</ref>
[[Tom Dumoulin]] won the 100th Giro in 2017, the first time ever that a Dutch cyclist won the Giro. He was also the first Dutchman to win the overall in a Grand Tour since [[Joop Zoetemelk]] won the 1980 Tour de France. A year later, [[Chris Froome]] won the 2018 Giro, becoming the first British rider to win the overall race.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

Pedalare! |chapter=The Heroic Age |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |year=2011 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eGBRfzR_onUC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-1-4088-1755-1 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Fotheringham |first1=William |title=Century of Cycling: The Classic Races and Legendary Champions |chapter=The Heroic Age |publisher=MBI Publishing Company |year=2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N2P_8ArwhPQC&pg=PT19&dq=ganna+1909+giro&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EtEzUeqiGYms8QT5qoG4Cg&ved=0CFEQ6AEwBw |isbn=978-0-7603-1553-8 |ref=harv}} {{Refend}}

revision.comment: /* top */http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox industrial process | name = Hytort process | image = | caption = | type = chemical | sector = [[Chemical industry]], [[oil industry]] | technologies = | feedstock = [[oil shale]] | product = [[shale oil]] | companies = | facility = | inventor = | year = | developer = [[Gas Technology Institute|Institute of Gas Technology]] }} The '''Hytort process''' is an above-ground [[shale oil extraction]] process developed by the [[Gas Technology Institute|Institute of Gas Technology]]. It is classified as a reactive fluid process,<ref name=AICHE> {{Cite conference | last = Burnham | first = Alan K. | last2 = McConaghy | first2 = James R. | title = Comparison of the acceptability of various oil shale processes | pages = 2; 17 | date = 2006-10-16 | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | conference = 26th Oil shale symposium | publisher = [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]] | url = https://e-reports-ext.llnl.gov/pdf/341283.pdf | format = PDF | id =UCRL-CONF-226717 | accessdate =2007-05-27}} </ref> which produces [[shale oil]] by [[hydrogenation]].
The Hytort process has advantages when processing oil shales containing less hydrogen, such as the eastern [[United States]] [[Devonian]] [[oil shale]]s. In this process, oil shale is processed at controlled heating rates in a high-pressure hydrogen environment, which allows a carbon conversion rate of around 80%.<ref name=hytort2> {{Cite paper | last=Weil |first=S. A. | last2=Feldkirchner |first2=H. L. | last3=Punwani |first3=D. V. | last4=Janka |first4= J. C. | publisher=[[Institute of Gas Technology]] | title=IGT HYTORT Process for hydrogen retorting of Devonian oil shales | date=1979-01-01 | id=CONF-790571-3}} </ref><ref name=encyclopedia > {{Cite book | last= McKetta |first=John J. | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=gb9UKnQEbeUC&pg=PA121 | publisher= [[CRC Press]] | title= Encyclopedia of Chemical Processing and Design: Volume 56 - Supercritical Fluid Technology: Theory and Application to Technology Forecasting | year=1996 | page= 121 | accessdate = 2010-02-13 | isbn=978-0-8247-2607-2}} </ref> Hydrogen reacts with coke [[Precursor (chemistry)|precursors]] (a chemical structure in the oil shale that is prone to form char during retorting but has not yet done so). In the case of Eastern US Devonian shales, the reaction roughly doubles the yield of oil, depending on the characteristics of the oil shale and process.<ref name=hytort> {{Cite book |last=Rex|first=R. |last2=Janka |first2=J. C. |last3=Knowlton |first3=T. |title=Cold Flow Model Testing of the Hytort Process Retort Design. 17th Oil Shale Symposium |publisher=Colorado School of Mines Press |pages=17–36 |year=1984}} </ref><ref name=lippmaa> {{Cite journal | last=Lippmaa |first= E. | last2=Maremäe |first2= E. | last3=Pihlak|first3= A.-T. | title= Resources, production and processing of Balstoscandian multimetal black shales | url = http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale_pdf/2011/issue_1/oil-2011-1-68-77.pdf | journal = [[Oil Shale (journal)|Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal]] | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 28 | issue =1 | pages = 68–77 | year =2011 | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | doi = 10.3176/oil.2011.1.08 | accessdate = 2011-10-29}} </ref>
In 1980, the HYCRUDE Corporation was established to commercialize the Hytort technology. The feasibility study was conducted by HYCRUDE Corporation, [[Phillips Petroleum Company]], [[Bechtel Group]] and the Institute of Gas Technology.<ref name=tippin > {{Cite conference | last1= Tippin |first1= R. Bruce | last2= Rex |first2= Raymond C. | url = http://www.anl.gov/PCS/acsfuel/preprint%20archive/Files/30_3_CHICAGO_09-85_0237.pdf | conference = Symposium on Chemistry and Processing Supercritical Fluids | title= Combined beneficiation and hydroretorting of oil shale | location = [[Chicago]] |date=September 1985 | pages = 237–246 | publisher = [[American Chemical Society]] | accessdate = 2010-02-13 | format = PDF}} </ref>
==See also== * [[Galoter process]] * [[Alberta Taciuk Process]] * [[Petrosix|Petrosix process]] * [[Kiviter process]] * [[TOSCO II process]] * [[Fushun process]] * [[Paraho process]] * [[Lurgi-Ruhrgas process]] * [[Chevron STB process]] * [[LLNL HRS process]] * [[KENTORT II]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Academic organizations]]; added [[Category:International learned societies]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''International Committee for the History of Technology''' (ICOHTEC) was founded at a meeting of the International Congress on the History of Science, Technology, and Medicine<ref>http://www.histnet.cnrs.fr/research/sfhst/spip.php?article222</ref> in Paris in the summer of 1968. Its founding was the brainchild of [[Melvin Kranzberg]], Professor of the History of Technology at [[Case Western Reserve University]] in Cleveland, Ohio, in the United States. Kranzberg had already established the [[Society for the History of Technology]] (SHOT) and its journal, ''[[Technology and Culture]]'', but he felt that in the midst of Cold War tensions, there was a need for another forum that focused on crossing the artificial borders of the Iron Curtain. For Kranzberg, the History of Technology, a new discipline not yet burdened with ideological or political freight as were other branches of history, was an ideal arena where scholars from East and West could find common ground. Kranzberg was supported in this effort by Maurice Daumas from France, Eugene Olszewski from Poland, and S.J. Schuchardine from the USSR, among others. For the past several decades, ICOHTEC's principal activity has been an ''annual meeting'',<ref>http://www.icohtec.org/annual-meeting-current.html</ref> where scholars from many countries and from many disclipines gather and share their work. Papers presented at the meetings are usually published in the Committee's annual journal ''ICON''.<ref>http://www.icohtec.org/publications-icon.htm</ref>
Kranzberg’s vision was largely fulfilled in the meetings that followed, although exchanges among scholars were not always harmonious. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the breakup of the Soviet Union in the years that followed, ICOHTEC lost its original reason for being. But it has thrived in the following years and continues to have an active international membership and hold well-attended and intellectually lively meetings. One reason is the perception that its sister society, SHOT, remains somewhat biased toward U.S. membership in spite of efforts to reach out more to an international audience. <!--
ICOHTEC had a very successful meeting [http://www.conferences.hu/ichs09/index.htm] in Budapest, Hungary in 2009.
In 2010 it held a joint meeting in Tampere, Finland with [[The International Committee for the Conservation of the Industrial Heritage]] (TICCIH) and The International Association of the Labour Museums (WORKLAB), around the theme ‘Reusing the Industrial Past’.
-->
==See also== *[[History of technology]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *'''[http://www.icohtec.org/ International Committee for the History of Technology]''' [[Category:International learned societies]] [[Category:History of technology]]
